The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao. The name that can be named is not the eternal name. The nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth; the named is the mother of the myriad things. Thus, always without desire, observe its mystery; always with desire, observe its manifestations. These two emerge together yet differ in name. Together they are called the profound. Profound and yet more profound—the gateway to all mysteries.

The Dao that can be spoken is not the eternal Dao. The eternal Dao cannot be spoken. If the eternal Dao cannot be spoken, can it then be named? The name that can be named is not the eternal name of the Dao. That which cannot be named is the very beginning of Heaven and Earth. Only after Heaven and Earth exist does the namable arise. This namable is truly the mother from which the myriad things are born. The Dao’s movement from nonbeing to being is thus.

Therefore, the sage who embodies the Dao constantly embodies its nonbeing to observe its mystery, without departing from being to observe its manifestations. Being and nonbeing serve as each other’s substance and function—there is fundamentally no duality, only differing names. Nonbeing is indeed profound, yet being is also not mere trace; together they are called the profound. But "profound" does not suffice to exhaust it—it is profound and yet again profound. Within this double profundity, all principles are complete. Is this not the gateway to all mysteries?

The Dao that can be spoken aligns with the *Doctrine of the Mean*’s "Dao that can be followed"—it is what people may follow in their conduct. Some punctuate "always without desire" and "always with desire" as separate phrases, taking "desire" to mean intention or emotion. They say: when without intention, observe the mystery of the Dao; when with intention, observe its manifestations. I contend that when one has desire, one is not without desire, and when one is without desire, one is not with desire. How then can one speak of "always without desire" and "always with desire"? Thus, the phrase should be punctuated after "nonbeing" and "being."

"Manifestations" (徼) are like the borders of a frontier—the furthest extent of things. Master Zhu said: "It resembles a boundary, the point where things connect." For when things reach their limit, there must be something that follows. Examples include the following chapter’s "beauty and ugliness" and "goodness and its absence." Only by paying attention to these points can one properly handle affairs. Su Ziyou said: "Anything distant and without limit must appear profound in color. Thus, Laozi often uses 'profound' to signify the ultimate."

Master Zhu said: "Profound means deep and remote, verging on darkness—where all mysteries reside."

This chapter is the guiding principle of the entire work. Hereafter, whenever speaking of the Dao’s essence, observe its mystery—the eternal Dao, the nameless. Whenever speaking of its application in affairs, observe its manifestations—the non-eternal Dao, the named.

When all under Heaven know beauty as beauty, ugliness arises. When all know goodness as goodness, its absence arises. Thus, being and nonbeing give rise to each other; difficulty and ease complete each other; long and short form each other; high and low incline toward each other; sound and voice harmonize with each other; front and back follow each other. Therefore, the sage practices nonaction in affairs and teaches without words. The myriad things arise without refusal, are born without possession, act without reliance, and succeed without dwelling. Precisely because they do not dwell, they do not depart.

When all under Heaven know beauty as beauty, they will vie to claim it, and beauty will no longer be true beauty. When all know goodness as goodness, they will compete to attach themselves to it, and goodness will no longer be true goodness. Originally beauty, yet it becomes ugliness; originally goodness, yet it becomes its absence. If one knows the reason beauty becomes ugliness and goodness becomes its absence, and handles them accordingly, then beauty will be truly beautiful and goodness truly good.

The mutual generation of beauty and ugliness, goodness and its absence, follows this cyclical principle. Thus, being and nonbeing give rise to each other; difficulty and ease complete each other; long and short form each other; high and low incline toward each other; sound and voice harmonize with each other; front and back follow each other—all are like this. Therefore, the sage, knowing this, practices nonaction in affairs and teaches without words. The myriad things arise before him, beauty and ugliness intermingled, yet he never refuses. He gives life to and nurtures the myriad things without claiming possession, governs affairs without relying on his ability, and when his work is complete, he does not dwell in it. Precisely because he does not dwell, his achievements endure and do not depart. In this way, beauty is not known as beauty, goodness is not known as goodness—yet beauty and goodness are thereby preserved.

This chapter’s first half exemplifies what was earlier called "observing its manifestations." At the furthest extent of beauty lies ugliness; at the furthest extent of ugliness lies beauty—this is true of all such pairs. Thus, what follows is observing manifestations to attain mystery.

Do not exalt worthiness, so the people do not contend. Do not prize rare goods, so the people do not steal. Do not display what is desirable, so their hearts are not confused. Therefore, in the sage’s governance: he empties their minds and fills their bellies, weakens their ambitions and strengthens their bones. He constantly keeps the people without knowledge and without desire, so that the knowledgeable dare not act. By acting through nonaction, nothing is left ungoverned.

If the ruler exalts worthiness, the people will distinguish themselves and contend for fame. If he does not exalt worthiness, they will not contend. If the ruler prizes rare goods, the people will compete for profit and even resort to theft. If he does not prize rare goods, they will not steal. If the ruler displays what is desirable, the people will desire it and their hearts will be confused. If he does not display what is desirable, the people’s hearts will not be confused.

The nature of the people is thus. Therefore, in the sage’s governance: when it comes to ornate matters, he ensures tranquility; when it comes to simple and unadorned affairs, he ensures fulfillment—this is emptying their minds and filling their bellies. When it comes to contentious tendencies, he ensures they are blocked; when it comes to self-reliance, he ensures it is esteemed—this is weakening their ambitions and strengthening their bones. He constantly keeps the people without discriminating knowledge and without covetous desire, and ensures that the clever dare not employ their private cunning to disrupt his governance.

What he practices is simply following the people’s nature without interference. Thus, nothing under Heaven is left ungoverned.

The four terms—mind, belly, ambition, and bones—are all metaphors.

The Dao is empty, yet its use is inexhaustible. Profound! It seems the ancestor of the myriad things. It blunts its sharpness, unties its tangles, softens its light, and merges with the dust. Deep! It seems to endure. I do not know whose child it is—it resembles the ancestor of the gods.

The Dao is empty and utterly without form, yet its use adapts to the myriad things without limit. None can exhaust its fullness. Profound! It resembles the ancestor and master of the myriad things. Those who embody the Dao must blunt their sharpness and not contend, untie the tangles of things without disturbance, soften their light and not dazzle, merge with the dust of things without severance. Deep and still, it seems to endure. I do not know whose child it is—it appears to precede even the gods.

Shao Bian notes: The two instances of *qi* (其) in the upper passage refer to oneself, while the two in the lower refer to others. The words *huo* (或, "perhaps"), *si* (似, "resembles"), *yan* (言, "speaks"), and *xiang* (象, "image") all refrain from asserting definitively—this is the subtlety of observing the constant and formless. Heaven and Earth are not benevolent; they treat the myriad things as straw dogs. The Sage is not benevolent; he treats the hundred clans as straw dogs. The space between Heaven and Earth—is it not like a bellows? Empty yet never exhausted, the more it moves, the more it brings forth. Much speech hastens exhaustion; better to abide in the center.

Heaven and Earth never bestow private favor upon things; they simply allow the myriad things to live and die of themselves, regarding them as straw dogs used in sacrifice—adorned when presented, not out of love; discarded after use, not out of hatred. All is as it naturally is. The Sage’s relation to the hundred clans is likewise without private favor; he follows the natural tendencies of the people without harming them, letting life and death, giving and taking proceed as they will, while he remains without intent. Is not the space between Heaven and Earth like the bellows of a smith? The bellows is empty within yet never exhausted; the more it moves, the more qi it emits. Heaven and Earth’s generation of the myriad things is just like this—what need is there for private favor? To understand Heaven and Earth is to understand the Sage. The Sage’s way of governing the people likewise has its own emptiness that never exhausts—this is what is called the center. Abiding in it suffices. Why exhaust oneself with much speech?

Jiao Shi comments: *Qu* (屈) means "pent-up," the sense of being restrained and unable to extend. The final two lines seem forced, as if making a separate point. Wang Chunfu suggests that Laozi, fearing later generations would misconstrue the straw-dog analogy, added this sigh—an interpretation that carries weight.

"The valley spirit does not die—this is called the mysterious female. The gate of the mysterious female—this is called the root of Heaven and Earth. Subtle and enduring, it seems to persist; its use is never strained."

The valley spirit does not perish with things—this is called the mysterious female. The gate of the mysterious female is whence Heaven and Earth arise—this is called the root of Heaven and Earth. Those who study the Dao embody this alone. Subtle and enduring, it seems to persist—not as persistence, but as persistence. Its use responds to things without strain—this is the use of the useless.

Jiao Shi says: The valley is a metaphor for its emptiness and capacity to receive, receiving without possessing. Subtle and wondrous, beyond measure, it is called the valley spirit. The female gives birth to the myriad things, as in the earlier chapter’s "mother." Calling it the mysterious female conveys its profound, unfathomable nature.

Xue Juncai says: *Pin* (牝) should be read like *bi* (匕) to rhyme with the preceding line. The phrase "the gate of the mysterious female" is an interpolated gloss, rhyming with the following line.

Su Shi says: Calling it the valley spirit describes its virtue; calling it the mysterious female describes its function. The female gives birth to the myriad things yet is called "mysterious"—this means it gives birth without revealing how it gives birth. This elaborates the opening chapter’s theme. "The valley spirit does not die" is what was called the constant Dao. "The gate of the mysterious female is called the root of Heaven and Earth" is what was called the nameless beginning of Heaven and Earth. "Subtle and enduring, it seems to persist"—this is the subtlety of observing the formless. "Its use is never strained"—this is the subtlety of observing the boundary. "Heaven is eternal, Earth everlasting. The reason Heaven and Earth can be eternal and everlasting is that they do not live for themselves—thus they can long endure. Therefore the Sage places himself behind, yet finds himself ahead; sets himself aside, yet finds himself preserved. Is it not because he is without self-interest that he can achieve his self-interest?"

Heaven is eternal, Earth everlasting. The reason Heaven and Earth can be eternal and everlasting is that they give life to things without claiming it as their own—thus they can long endure. If Heaven and Earth were to claim their life as their own, they would be but one thing among things—how could they be eternal and everlasting? Therefore the Sage dwells in softness and lowliness, fundamentally placing himself behind, yet finds himself ahead. Without desires or demands, fundamentally setting himself aside, yet finds himself preserved. Is it not because his heart is without self-interest that he achieves his self-interest? His being behind and preserved follows inevitably from principle and circumstance.

"The highest good is like water. Water benefits the myriad things without contention, dwelling in places all others shun—thus it is near the Dao. In dwelling, it favors the lowly; in heart, it favors the profound; in giving, it favors benevolence; in speech, it favors trust; in governance, it favors order; in affairs, it favors ability; in movement, it favors timeliness. It is only because it does not contend that it is without blame."

The highest human good resembles water. Water’s nature is to benefit the myriad things without contention. People all prefer the high, yet it alone descends to dwell in places all others shun—thus it is near the Dao. The highest good in a person: in dwelling, it favors the lowly, finding no place that is not secure—like water flowing, stopping in hollows. In heart, it favors the profound, still and unfathomable—like water’s emptiness and silence. In giving, it favors benevolence, nourishing and benefiting all things—like water’s moisture sustaining all life. In speech, it favors trust, never forsaking its course—like water flowing through peril without fail. In governance, it favors order, cleansing impurities and leveling high and low—like water washing away filth and balancing disparities. In affairs, it favors ability, adapting in myriad ways—like water dissolving hardness and penetrating the minute, reaching everywhere. In movement, it favors timeliness, ever-changing—like water avoiding the high and seeking the low, flowing without stagnation. Possessing all these virtues and yet able to refrain from contention—only because it does not contend is it free from blame in the world. This is why the highest good resembles water.

"To hold and fill it is not as good as stopping. To measure and sharpen it cannot be long preserved. When gold and jade fill the hall, none can keep them. Wealth and nobility breed arrogance, leaving one’s own fault behind. When merit is achieved and fame established, withdraw—this is the Dao of Heaven."

To cling and fill is not as secure as ceasing. To measure and sharpen is to fail to recognize that sharpness cannot be long preserved. When gold and jade fill the hall, none can guard them—what use is filling? Wealth and nobility breed arrogance, leaving one’s own fault behind—what use is sharpness? One should follow the Dao of Heaven alone: when merit is achieved and fame established, withdraw. To have yet not possess—this is not what is called filling. To act in accord with principle—this is not what is called sharpness.
chunks.overlap_context: Dao is empty and utterly without form, yet its use adapts to the myriad things without limit. None can exhaust its fullness. Profound! It resembles the ancestor and master of the myriad things. Those who embody the Dao must blunt their sharpness and not contend, untie the tangles of things without disturbance, soften their light and not dazzle, merge with the dust of things without severance. Deep and still, it seems to endure. I do not know whose child it is—it appears to precede even the gods.

chunks.original_text: 诸本多解作持其盈揣其锐 载营魄抱一能无离乎专气致柔能婴儿乎涤除玄览能无疵乎爱民治国能无为乎天门开阖能无雌乎明白四达能无知乎生之畜之生而不有为而不恃长而不宰是谓玄德 心役于物则营与魄离人之载营于魄而抱一者能常相守而不离乎心使气则气乱人之专守其气以致柔能如婴儿之纯乎私累不尽则神有所蔽人之涤除尘垢玄通旷览者能无疵乎身既治而治人爱民治国能清静坐理而无为乎天门开阖以应事变能为雌而不为雄乎既于事理明白四达能晦默若无知乎能如此则于天下之民生之畜之生之而不自以为有为之而不恃其劳长之而不任己意以宰制之是为深远难名之德 朱子曰魂阳动而魄阴静魂火二而魄水一故曰载营魄抱一能无离乎言以魂加魄以动守静以火迫水以二守一而不相离如人登车而载于其上则魂安静而魄精明火不燥而水不溢固长生久视之要诀也 玄览即观妙观徼之观天门指心开阖心之运动变化也 三十辐共一毂当其无有车之用埏埴以为器当其无有器之用凿户牖以为室当其无有室之用故有之以为利无之以为用 三十辐共一毂当无毂之处乃有车之用埏埴以为器当无器之处乃有器之用凿户牖以为室当无室之处乃有室之用有资于无如此故天下之理皆有之以为利无之以为用非有则无利而用之质亡矣非无则无用而利之机滞矣无非有不可也有非无亦不可也 五色令人目盲五音令人耳聋五味令人口爽驰骋畋猎令人心发狂难得之货令人行妨是以圣人为腹不为目故去彼取此 目以视色五色眩目而目为之盲耳以察音五音沸耳而耳为之聋口以尝味五味饫口而口为之爽田猎以自娱驰骋不已而心为之发狂货以利用好其难得而行为之妨岂非贪为之患哉逐乎外而无厌者目也止于内而易足者腹也是以圣人为腹之易足不为目之无厌故去彼外逐而取此内止也 宠辱若惊贵大患若身何谓宠辱若惊宠为下得也若惊失之若惊是谓宠辱若惊何谓贵大患若身吾所以有大患者为吾有身及吾无身吾有何患故贵以身为天下者可以寄天下爱以身为天下者可以托天下 古之达人宠辱皆若惊视宠犹辱也 重大患如身同身于患也 何谓宠辱若惊人莫不以宠为上而辱为下若知辱生于宠宠为辱先则宠固为下矣 故得之若惊讶辱之将至也 失之亦若惊幸辱之可免也 何谓重大患若身吾所以有大患者为吾之自有其身耳 自有其身则爱身之情过笃而人世得失之事皆足为难矣 吾能后其身外其身是不有其身也 不有其身则死生荣辱可以一致复有何患乎 进而推之人之不有其身者必不以得天下为荣而贵以身为天下矣 斯人也 真可寄以天下者也 人之不有其身者必能不自生而生人而爱以身为天下矣 斯人也 真可托以天下者也

The various editions often interpret this as "holding to fullness and measuring sharpness." "Carrying the hun-soul and embracing the one—can they not be separated? Concentrating qi to attain softness—can one be like an infant? Cleansing and purifying profound vision—can it be without flaw? Loving the people and governing the state—can one do so without action? The gates of Heaven open and close—can one remain receptive? Understanding the four directions—can one be without knowledge? Giving life and nurturing, giving life yet not possessing, acting yet not relying, growing yet not dominating—this is called profound virtue."

When the heart is enslaved by things, the hun and po souls separate. For one who carries the hun-soul within the po and embraces the one—can they constantly guard and not part? When the heart manipulates qi, qi becomes disordered. For one who concentrates and guards their qi to attain softness—can they be as pure as an infant? When private attachments are not exhausted, the spirit is obscured. For one who cleanses and removes the dust of the world to achieve profound and boundless vision—can it be without flaw? When the body is already governed and one governs others, loving the people and governing the state—can one sit in clarity and principle without action? The gates of Heaven open and close in response to changing affairs—can one act as the receptive and not as the assertive? Having thoroughly understood the principles of affairs in all four directions—can one remain obscure as if without knowledge? If one can do this, then for the people of the world, one gives life and nurtures, gives life yet does not claim possession, acts yet does not rely on effort, grows yet does not impose one’s will to dominate—this is the virtue that is deep, far-reaching, and difficult to name.

Master Zhu said: The hun is yang, moving; the po is yin, still. The hun is fire, two; the po is water, one. Thus it is said, "Carrying the hun-soul and embracing the one—can they not be separated?" This means applying the hun to the po, using movement to guard stillness, using fire to press upon water, using two to guard one, and not allowing them to separate. It is like a person mounting a chariot and being carried upon it: the hun is at peace, the po is clear, fire does not scorch, and water does not overflow. This is truly the essential formula for long life and enduring vision.

"Profound vision" is the vision of the wondrous and the subtle. "The gates of Heaven" refer to the heart’s opening and closing, the heart’s movements and transformations.

"Thirty spokes share one hub—it is in their nothingness that the use of the chariot lies. Clay is shaped to form a vessel—it is in its nothingness that the use of the vessel lies. Doors and windows are cut to make a room—it is in their nothingness that the use of the room lies. Thus, being is for the sake of benefit, nothingness is for the sake of use."

Thirty spokes share one hub—it is where there is no hub that the use of the chariot lies. Clay is shaped to form a vessel—it is where there is no vessel that the use of the vessel lies. Doors and windows are cut to make a room—it is where there is no room that the use of the room lies. The reliance on nothingness is like this. Therefore, the principles of the world all have being for the sake of benefit and nothingness for the sake of use. Without being, nothingness has no benefit and the substance of use is lost. Without nothingness, use has no benefit and the mechanism of benefit is obstructed. Nothingness cannot exist without being, and being cannot exist without nothingness.

"The five colors blind the eyes. The five tones deafen the ears. The five flavors dull the palate. Racing and hunting madden the heart. Rare goods hinder conduct. Therefore, the sage is for the belly, not for the eyes—thus he discards that and takes this."

The eyes are for seeing colors; the five colors dazzle the eyes and blind them. The ears are for discerning sounds; the five tones overwhelm the ears and deafen them. The mouth is for tasting flavors; the five flavors satiate the mouth and dull it. Hunting for amusement, racing without cease—these madden the heart. Goods are for practical use; coveting what is hard to obtain hinders conduct. Is this not the harm of greed? That which pursues externals without satiety is the eyes; that which is content within and easily satisfied is the belly. Therefore, the sage is for the belly’s easy satisfaction, not for the eyes’ insatiable desires—thus he discards external pursuit and takes internal contentment.

"Favor and disgrace are like surprise; value great trouble as you do your body. What does it mean, 'Favor and disgrace are like surprise'? Favor is inferior—gaining it is like surprise, losing it is like surprise. This is what is meant by 'favor and disgrace are like surprise.' What does it mean, 'Value great trouble as you do your body'? The reason I have great trouble is that I have a body. When I no longer have a body, what trouble do I have? Therefore, one who values their body for the sake of the world can be entrusted with the world. One who cherishes their body for the sake of the world can be entrusted with the world."

The enlightened of old regarded favor and disgrace as equally surprising, valuing great trouble as they did their own bodies.

What does it mean, "Favor and disgrace are like surprise"? People invariably consider favor superior and disgrace inferior. If one knows that disgrace arises from favor and favor precedes disgrace, then favor is inherently inferior. Thus, gaining it is like surprise at the impending disgrace, and losing it is like surprise at the possibility of avoiding disgrace.

What does it mean, "Value great trouble as you do your body"? The reason I have great trouble is that I possess my own body. If I possess my body, love for it becomes excessive, and the gains and losses of the world all become troubles. If I can place my body after others and treat it as external, this is not possessing it. Not possessing it, life and death, honor and disgrace can be unified—what trouble remains? Extending this further, one who does not possess their body will not consider gaining the world as honor and thus values their body for the world. Such a person is truly one to whom the world can be entrusted. One who does not possess their body will not live for themselves but live for others, cherishing their body for the world. Such a person is truly one to whom the world can be entrusted.

chunks.original_text: 贵重也 难也 视之不见名曰夷听之不闻名曰希抟之不得名曰微此三者不可致诘故混而为一其上不皦其下不昧绳绳兮不可名复归于无物是谓无状之状无物之象是谓惚恍迎之不见其首随之不见其后执古之道以御今之有能知古始是谓道纪 视之而不见因名曰夷听之而不闻因名曰希抟之而不得因名曰微此三名皆强名也 实则不可致诘故混而为一凡物之有形者皆有明昧此则上不皦而下不昧无形之可求也 绳绳兮往过来续于日用之间若有物可名而实不可名复归于无物而已是谓无状之状无物之象是谓惚而可执以为有恍而不可执以为无迎而求之莫知其所自来也 随而究之莫知其所自终也 自古有之谓之曰道人有执古之道以御今日所有之事物者身在今日而能知古初无物之始矣 是谓道之统绪约略也 通章皆极赞道体之妙 古之善为士者微妙玄通深不可识夫唯不可识故强为之容豫若冬渉川犹若畏四邻俨若客涣若冰将释敦兮其若朴旷兮其若谷混兮其若浊孰能浊以静之徐清孰能安以久动之徐生保此道者不欲盈夫唯不盈故能敝不新成 古之善为士者微矣 妙矣 玄矣

Valuing is heaviness; difficulty is weight. Look for it and it cannot be seen—this is called "subtle." Listen for it and it cannot be heard—this is called "rare." Grasp for it and it cannot be held—this is called "minute." These three cannot be exhaustively questioned, so they merge into one. Above, it is not bright; below, it is not dark. Endless and unceasing, it cannot be named, returning again to nothingness. This is called the form without form, the image without thing—this is called "elusive and vague." Meet it and you cannot see its beginning; follow it and you cannot see its end. Hold fast to the ancient Dao to master today’s being. To know the ancient beginning is called the thread of the Dao.

Look for it and it cannot be seen—thus it is named "subtle." Listen for it and it cannot be heard—thus it is named "rare." Grasp for it and it cannot be held—thus it is named "minute." These three names are all forced designations, for in truth they cannot be exhaustively questioned, so they merge into one. All things with form have brightness and darkness, but this has neither brightness above nor darkness below—no form to seek. Endless and unceasing, it passes and continues in daily use. Though it seems there is something to name, in truth it cannot be named, returning again to nothingness. This is called the form without form, the image without thing—this is called "elusive yet graspable as being, vague yet not graspable as nothingness." Seek it in advance and you cannot know whence it comes; pursue it afterward and you cannot know where it ends. Existing since antiquity, it is called the Dao. One who holds fast to the ancient Dao to master today’s affairs, though dwelling in the present, can know the beginning when there was nothing—this is called the lineage and essence of the Dao.

The entire passage extols the wonder of the Dao’s essence. The ancients who were good as scholars were subtle, wondrous, profound, and penetrating—so deep they could not be known. Precisely because they could not be known, one can only forcefully describe their demeanor: hesitant, as if crossing a river in winter; cautious, as if fearing neighbors on all sides; solemn, as if a guest; melting, as if ice about to thaw; simple, as if uncarved wood; open, as if a valley; turbid, as if muddy water. Who can make the turbid clear through stillness? Gradually it becomes clear. Who can make the tranquil enduring through movement? Gradually it comes to life. Those who preserve this Dao do not desire fullness. Precisely because they are not full, they can remain worn yet not newly made.

The ancients who were good as scholars were subtle, wondrous, profound, and unfathomable.

chunks.original_text: 通矣 其深不可得而识也 夫唯不可识故但强为之容豫兮若渉川之难之也 犹兮若畏四邻之慎之也 俨若客之无惰也 涣若冰释之无所凝滞也 敦兮其若朴之厚重也 旷兮其若谷之虚受也 浑兮其若浊之晦默也 盛德之容盖如此其微妙玄通者终不可得而识也 古之士何以致此哉 亦惟浊以静之徐清安以动之徐生而已今之人皆昭昭以为清耳 孰能浊以静之而徐自清皆争先以为生耳 孰能安以久而不妄动动之而因应徐生者乎 大抵保此道者不欲自盈盈则心不虚而道不可保矣 夫唯不盈则能安其敝能不求新成则其所以静而徐清动而徐生微妙玄通之域可企而至也 能敝能不新成即浊也安以久也 极形盛德之妙而示人入德之方 致虚极守静笃万物并作吾以观其复夫物芸芸各归其根归根曰静静曰复命复命曰常知常曰明不知常妄作凶知常容容乃公公乃王王乃天天乃道道乃久没身不殆 致虚至于极守静至于笃万物并作于前吾不与之作而以观其复万物之作芸芸然矣 我观复则不见其芸芸而与之各归其根夫物之芸芸者归其根则万物无足动我者是之谓静是之谓复命命者我生之本然也 复其本然则无动也 亦无静也 谓之常而已知常者非微妙玄通之士不足以几之故曰明不知此常则未免妄作而致凶人知常则善恶两忘何所不容能容则徧覆无私何有不公公则可以为斯民之主而王王又不足以尽之而合乎 始万物之天先天地之道人与道合体斯可以久而没身不殆矣 极言虚静之效其入手在观复观复即首章观徼也 太上不知有之其次亲之誉之其次畏之其次侮之信不足有不信犹兮其贵言功成事遂百姓皆谓我自然【不知有之诸本并作下知有之】 太上盛治之君下但知有之而已其次则民亲之誉之又其次则畏之又其次则侮之其递降而至致侮者何故惟上之信有不足故民有不信而至于侮也民既不信虽多言何益乎若太上之君则不然犹兮贵重其言而不轻出使民阴受其赐及功成事遂百姓皆以为我自如此不知谁之所为也所以下但知有之也 大道废有仁义智慧出有大伪六亲不和有孝慈国家昏乱有忠臣 大道之行也民不知有仁义大道废而后仁义见矣民本相忘于朴智慧者出而自矜其明则民各以智相尚而大伪从此起矣六亲方和孝慈不着人尽孝且慈也不和而后有孝慈矣国家方治忠臣不见臣尽忠也国家昏乱而后有忠臣矣 绝圣弃智民利百倍绝仁弃义民复孝慈绝巧弃利盗贼无有此三者以为文不足故令有所属见素抱朴少私寡欲 以圣智相尚则民各奋其智能而苦于多事绝圣弃智民利百倍矣以仁义为美则人骛于名而孝慈之实衰绝仁弃义民复孝慈矣以巧相御以利相夸则民多贪诈而至于为盗绝巧弃利盗贼无有矣此三者圣人以为皆文也皆不足者也故令绝之弃之而他有所属惟见其质抱其朴少所私寡所欲以庶几于无为之治焉 此章与前章紧相应 绝学无忧唯之与阿相去几何善之与恶相去何若人之所畏不可不畏荒兮其未央哉众人熙熙如享太牢如春登台我独怕兮其未兆如婴儿之未孩乘乘兮若无所归众人皆有余而我独若遗我愚人之心也哉沌沌兮俗人昭昭我独若昏俗人察察我独闷闷忽兮若晦寂兮似无所止众人皆有以我独顽似鄙我独异于人而贵食母【焦氏云怕古泊字静也】 人绝去世俗名象之学则无分别计较之忧如唯阿善恶世学之所务别也 自我观之唯之与阿相去几何乎
chunks.translated_text:
Perfected is it—so deep it cannot be grasped or known. Precisely because it cannot be known, one can only forcefully describe its demeanor: hesitant, as if fording a river’s peril; cautious, as if wary of neighbors on all sides; solemn, as if a guest without laxity; melting, as if ice dissolving without obstruction; simple, as if uncarved wood’s weightiness; open, as if a valley’s empty receptivity; turbid, as if muddy water’s obscurity. The bearing of great virtue is thus—so subtle, wondrous, and profoundly penetrating that it ultimately cannot be grasped or known. How did the scholars of old attain this? Only by making the turbid clear through stillness, gradually; making the tranquil enduring through movement, gradually. Nowadays, people all clamor to be bright, thinking themselves clear—who can make the turbid still and slowly clarify? They all vie to be first, thinking themselves alive—who can remain tranquil, enduring, and not recklessly move, moving only to respond and gradually come to life?

Generally, those who preserve this Dao do not desire fullness. When full, the heart is not empty, and the Dao cannot be preserved. Only by not being full can one remain at ease in weariness, not seeking renewal. Thus, in stillness, one gradually clarifies; in movement, one gradually comes to life. The realm of subtlety, wonder, and profound penetration may be aspired to and attained. To be worn yet not newly made is to be turbid; to remain tranquil and enduring is to be at peace. This fully expresses the marvel of great virtue and reveals the path to entering it.

Attain utmost emptiness; guard absolute stillness. As the myriad things arise together, I observe their return. Things flourish abundantly, each returning to its root. Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called returning to life’s mandate; returning to life’s mandate is called constancy. Knowing constancy is called illumination. Not knowing constancy leads to reckless action and misfortune. Knowing constancy allows all-embracing capacity; capacity leads to impartiality; impartiality leads to kingship; kingship leads to Heaven; Heaven leads to the Dao; the Dao leads to enduring. One’s body will not be imperiled.

Attaining utmost emptiness, guarding absolute stillness—when the myriad things arise before me, I do not act with them but observe their return. The arising of the myriad things is profuse, yet I see their return: they do not appear profuse but each returns to its root. When things return to their root, nothing can disturb me—this is called stillness; this is called returning to life’s mandate. Life’s mandate is the natural state of my existence. Returning to this natural state, there is neither movement nor stillness—it is called constancy alone. Those who know constancy are not mere scholars of subtlety, wonder, and profound penetration; thus it is called illumination. Not knowing this constancy leads to reckless action and misfortune. Knowing constancy, good and evil are both forgotten—what cannot be embraced? With capacity, one universally covers all without partiality—what is not impartial? Impartiality allows one to be a ruler of the people and a king. Kingship is not yet the ultimate; it harmonizes with the Heaven that precedes the myriad things, the Dao that precedes Heaven. When humans unite with the Dao in body, they can endure, and their bodies will not be imperiled.

This exhaustively speaks of the efficacy of emptiness and stillness. The entry point lies in observing return—observing return is the "observing subtleties" of the first chapter.

The highest rulers—those below merely know they exist. The next are those the people draw near to and praise; the next are those they fear; the next are those they revile. When trust is insufficient, there is distrust. Hesitant, they value their words. When tasks are accomplished and affairs settled, the common people all say, "We are naturally so." [Some versions read: "The highest rulers—those below do not know they exist."]

The highest rulers in times of great governance—those below merely know they exist. The next are those the people draw near to and praise; the next are those they fear; the next are those they revile. Why does it descend to the point of revilement? Because the rulers’ trust is insufficient, so the people lack trust and come to revile them. When the people lack trust, what use are many words? Between good and evil, how great is the distance? Simply let it be—what need is there for learning, what need for sorrow? Yet what others fear, I too cannot but fear; I dare not treat it with neglect. However, following principle and observing measure, beyond this the heart holds no concern. How vast and boundless is this heart—its limits are nowhere to be found.

What others delight in, I have never indulged as pleasure. While the multitude revels, radiant as if feasting on grand sacrifices or ascending a terrace in spring, I alone remain still, without sign of desire, like an infant who has not yet smiled. Fear and joy alike cannot burden me; I only feel my heart drifting, as if with nowhere to return, unshackled from private attachments. The multitude all have more than enough, while I alone seem lacking, unclinging to possession. My heart is that of a foolish person—so muddled! The common people are bright, as if knowing; I alone am dim. The common people are sharp, intent on distinctions; I alone am dull. Vast, as if obscure; still, as if without abode. The multitude all have purpose; I alone am stubborn, like a rustic. In this state of carefree unconcern, how can I be thus?

While others rush to learning, I alone sever myself from it, returning to the origin of all things to nourish myself. The bearing of great virtue follows only the Dao. The Dao as a thing is only vague and elusive: elusive, yet within it there are images; vague, yet within it there are forms. Profound, obscure—within it there is essence. Its essence is utterly real, within it there is trustworthiness. From ancient times to the present, its name has never departed, by which we may observe the origins of all things. How do I know the nature of these origins? By this.

The appearance of one of abundant virtue is to follow only the Dao. What is the wonder of the Dao’s essence? The Dao as a thing is only vague and elusive—it cannot be seen. Though unseen, within its elusiveness there are images, within its vagueness there are forms, within its profundity and obscurity there is essence. Its essence is utterly real and not false, within it there is trustworthiness that may be relied upon. This is the Dao. From ancient times to the present, its name has never departed, by which we may observe the origins of all things. How do I know that the origins of all things are observed through the Dao? Precisely because the Dao’s essence is vague, elusive, profound, and obscure—unchanging and indestructible—thus all things pass through transformation with it, while the Dao alone remains constant.

Wang Chunfu says: "阅 means to experience." All things under heaven, all that issues from the Dao, are included. Wang Fusi says: "阅 means that which emerges from the gate, each counted one by one. The Dao is like a gate—all things pass through it."

That which is bent becomes whole, that which is crooked becomes straight, that which is hollow becomes full, that which is worn becomes new, that which is little attains, that which is much confounds. Therefore the sage embraces the One and serves as the model for the world. He does not display himself, and so is enlightened; he does not assert himself, and so is distinguished; he does not boast of his achievements, and so has merit; he does not exalt himself, and so endures. It is only because he does not contend that no one in the world can contend with him. Is what the ancients called "that which is bent becomes whole" an empty saying? Truly, wholeness returns to it.

All things follow this principle: that which is bent may become whole, that which is crooked may become straight, that which is hollow may become full, that which is worn may become new, that which is little may attain, that which is much may be confounded. This is the unchanging pattern of growth and decline. Therefore the sage merely embraces the One and does not seek more, serving as the model for the world. He does not display his enlightenment, and so is enlightened; he does not assert himself to seek distinction, and so is distinguished; he does not boast of his achievements, and so has merit; he does not exalt himself, and so endures. This is the way of non-contention. Only because he does not contend does no one in the world contend with him. If one were to say there is still contention with him, how could the ancients’ saying that "that which is bent becomes whole" be an empty word? The trouble lies only in one’s inability to bend. If one bends, truly wholeness returns to it—the principle of things cannot be denied.

Few words are natural. A whirlwind does not last the morning; a sudden rain does not last the day. Who brings these about? Heaven and Earth. If even Heaven and Earth cannot make them last, how much less can man? Therefore, those who act in accordance with the Dao become one with the Dao; those who act in accordance with virtue become one with virtue; those who act in accordance with loss become one with loss. One who is one with the Dao, the Dao also delights in attaining; one who is one with virtue, virtue also delights in attaining; one who is one with loss, loss also delights in attaining. When trust is insufficient, there is distrust.

If one speaks rarely, following nature without concern, this is sufficient. A whirlwind does not last the morning; a sudden rain does not last the day—who brings these about? Heaven and Earth. If even Heaven and Earth cannot make such things last long, how much more difficult is it for man to contend with others through his own cunning and intelligence? Therefore, those who act in accordance with the Dao do not do so: when they encounter the Dao, they forget it in the Dao; when they encounter virtue, they forget it in virtue; when they encounter loss, they forget it in loss. It is merely a matter of few words, of following nature. One who is one with the Dao, the Dao delights in attaining; one who is one with virtue, virtue delights in attaining; one who is one with loss, loss delights in attaining. It is because all people, wise and foolish alike, live in harmony with it that this trust exists. If trust were insufficient, no matter how many words one used to contend, there would still be distrust. How greatly to be valued is the sufficiency of few words and naturalness!

One who stands on tiptoe does not stand firm; one who takes long strides does not walk far. One who displays himself is not enlightened; one who asserts himself is not distinguished; one who boasts of his achievements has no merit; one who exalts himself does not endure. In the Dao, these are called "excess food and redundant conduct"—things that others may detest. Therefore, one who has the Dao does not dwell in them.

One who stands on tiptoe to be taller cannot stand firm; one who takes long strides to walk faster cannot walk far. Those in the world who display themselves to seek enlightenment, assert themselves to seek distinction, boast of their achievements, or exalt themselves—how are they different? In the Dao, these are like leftover food or redundant conduct—things that others may detest. Therefore, one who has the Dao does not dwell in them. *Jiao Shi says: "行 in 赘行 should be 形, as the ancient characters are interchangeable."*

There is a thing, formless yet complete, born before Heaven and Earth. Silent, empty, it stands alone and does not change, it moves in cycles and does not weary. It may be considered the mother of all under Heaven. I do not know its name; I style it "Dao"; forced to give it a name, I call it "great." Great means it flows ever onward; flowing ever onward means it is far-reaching; far-reaching means it returns. Therefore the Dao is great, Heaven is great, Earth is great, and the king is also great. Within the realm there are four greats, and the king occupies one of them. Man models himself on Earth; Earth models itself on Heaven; Heaven models itself on the Dao; the Dao models itself on nature.

There is a thing born before Heaven and Earth, yet we know not whence it first arose. As a thing, it is silent and empty, standing alone without peer, enduring through ancient and modern times without change, circulating through the ten thousand beings without ever wearying. The ten thousand things arise from it without exception—it may be called the mother of all under Heaven. I do not know its name; I style it "Dao"; forced to give it a name, I call it merely "great." Its greatness lies in transforming without possessing—this may also be called "flowing onward." Its flowing onward is all-encompassing without boundary—this may also be called "far-reaching." In a single thought, seeking it, one finds it—this may also be called "returning." Flowing onward, far-reaching, returning—these together complete its greatness.

Thus the Dao is great, Heaven is great, Earth is great, and the king is also great. Within the realm there are four greats, and the king occupies one of them. Should one not reflect on how to preserve this greatness? To preserve it, one must model oneself on Earth’s capacity to bear all without exception. Beyond Earth is Heaven—one must model oneself on Heaven’s capacity to cover all without exception. That which gives birth to Heaven and Earth is the Dao—one must model oneself on the Dao’s capacity to give birth to all, to bring all to completion without exception. The Dao is fundamentally nature; to model oneself on the Dao is merely to model oneself on its naturalness. The last four sentences speak from a human perspective; if one clings to their wording, they become difficult to comprehend.

The heavy is the root of the light; stillness is the lord of restlessness. Therefore the sage, though traveling all day, does not part from the baggage train. Though dwelling in splendor, he remains detached. How could a lord of ten thousand chariots treat his person lightly before the world? To be light is to lose one’s root; to be restless is to lose one’s lordship.

In all things, the heavy commonly supports the light—thus the heavy is the root of the light. The still commonly governs the restless—thus stillness is the lord of restlessness. Therefore the sage, traveling all day, does not part from the baggage train, holding fast to the heavy to avoid losing the light. Though dwelling in splendor, he remains detached within it, holding fast to stillness to avoid losing his lordship. How could one who rules ten thousand chariots gallop recklessly through the world’s trifles? To be light is to lose what makes one a root and have nothing to rely upon. To be restless is to lose what makes one a lord and have nothing to govern.

The baggage train serves as a metaphor for not straying from one’s foundation; "splendor" refers to palaces, terraces, and pavilions—metaphors for positions of honor.

The good traveler leaves no tracks; the good speaker leaves no flaws; the good reckoner needs no counting rods; the good locker needs no bolt yet cannot be opened; the good binder needs no rope yet cannot be untied. Thus the sage is always good at saving people, and so leaves no one behind; always good at saving things, and so leaves nothing behind. This is called inheriting enlightenment.

Therefore the good person is the teacher of the not-good; the not-good person is the resource of the good. If one does not value one’s teacher or cherish one’s resource, though wise, one is greatly deluded. This is called the essential subtlety.

The good traveler leaves no tracks because they travel as they ought. The good speaker leaves no flaws because they speak as they ought. The good reckoner needs no counting rods because their reasoning must reach its mark. The good locker needs no bolt yet cannot be opened because they grasp the essential. The good binder needs no rope yet cannot be untied because all share the same desire.

The sage possesses these virtues and thus always governs people by means of people. This is the goodness of saving people, so each person finds their place and none are abandoned. The sage always entrusts things to things. This is the goodness of saving things, so each thing fulfills its nature and none are discarded. This is called skillfully employing one’s enlightenment to govern people and things.

All people under Heaven, whether good or not, are encompassed within this. The good person is the teacher of the not-good; the not-good person is the resource of the good. Knowing them as teachers, one values them; knowing them as resources, one cherishes them. Thus in dealing with the good and the not-good, each finds their proper place. This is what it means to save people without abandoning anyone.

If one does not value one’s teacher or cherish one’s resource, though one may consider oneself wise, one is in fact greatly deluded. This teacher and resource—between them lies the essential subtlety of saving people, which depends on skillful use.

"Inheriting enlightenment" means to transmit and apply one’s own enlightenment to people and things.

One interpretation likens it to the "enveloping" of a robe—using one’s enlightenment with subtle density. "Knowing the male but guarding the female, one becomes the world’s valley-stream." As the world’s valley-stream, constant virtue does not depart, returning to the state of an infant. "Knowing the white but guarding the black, one becomes the world’s model." As the world’s model, constant virtue knows no flaw, returning to the formless limit. "Knowing glory but guarding disgrace, one becomes the world’s valley." As the world’s valley, constant virtue is fully realized, returning to uncarved simplicity.

When simplicity scatters, it becomes vessels; the sage employs it to become the leader of officials. Thus, great governance does not sever. Though one may know the male and employ its strength, one guards the female and takes softness as primary—placing oneself in lowliness to become the world’s valley-stream. As the world’s valley-stream, constant virtue embraces and does not depart, returning to the selfless state of an infant. Though one may know the white and employ brightness, one guards the black and takes obscurity as primary—constantly humbling oneself to become the world’s model. As the world’s model, constant virtue knows no flaw, returning to the formless limit. Though one may know glory and exalt oneself, one guards disgrace and takes retreat as primary—containing impurity to become the world’s valley. As the world’s valley, constant virtue is fully realized, returning to undifferentiated simplicity.

Simplicity cannot be named as a single vessel; when it scatters, it becomes vessels, each merely the guardian of one office. The sage employs it so that vessels revert to simplicity, not serving as officials but as the leader of officials. Thus, governing the world with the great Dao does not involve the petty art of cutting and dividing.

The character *shi* (式) has been variously interpreted; in my humble opinion, since *xi* (溪, valley-stream) and *gu* (谷, valley) are borrowed usages, *shi* likely refers to the crossbar of a chariot—a device for measuring time, also called *shi*. Just as one aligns oneself to it without intent, so too does the sage act.

Those who seek to take the world and act upon it—I see they will not succeed. The world is a sacred vessel and cannot be acted upon. Those who act upon it ruin it; those who grasp it lose it. Thus, things may proceed or follow, exhale warmth or blow cold, be strong or weak, bear or destroy. Therefore, the sage eliminates excess, extravagance, and extremity.

Those who seek to take the world through action or control—I see they will not attain it. Why? The world is originally a weighty vessel of spiritual power and cannot be forcibly shaped by one person’s private wisdom. Those who act upon it will ruin it; those who grasp it will lose it. Thus, among the world’s things, some advance while others follow, some exhale warmth while others blow cold, some are strong and competitive while others are weak and self-preserving, some bear and complete while others collapse and destroy. Their natures differ, and their choices vary; to impose one will upon them is difficult. Therefore, the sage follows their natural course without imposing intent, merely removing excess, extravagance, and extremity—nothing more. Why must there be further action?

Those who assist a ruler with the Dao do not use military force to dominate the world, for such affairs rebound. Where armies march, brambles grow; after great wars, years of famine follow. The good warrior achieves results but does not dare to seize strength. Achieve results but do not boast; achieve results but do not vaunt; achieve results but do not be arrogant; achieve results out of necessity; achieve results but do not force it. Things in their prime inevitably age—this is called "not following the Dao." Those who do not follow the Dao perish early.

Those who assist a ruler with the Dao do not use military force to dominate the world, for warfare tends to rebound. Where armies camp, brambles grow; after great wars, years of famine follow. The harm of warfare is thus—how can it be used to assist a ruler in dominating the world? What is called "skillful use of arms" lies in decisive action alone, not daring to seize strength. How does one achieve results? Achieve results without boasting; achieve results without vaunting; achieve results without arrogance; achieve results out of necessity; achieve results without forcing it. The principle of fullness and emptiness in the world is that all things in their prime inevitably age. Using arms to seize strength is called "relying on prime and not following the Dao." Those who do not follow the Dao perish early—how can they remain strong for long?

Master Jiao said: "Acting out of necessity is difficult." The five instances of *er* (而, "but") following "achieve results" should be read as *yu* (于, "in"). Others may achieve results there, but I alone achieve results here.

Fine weapons are inauspicious tools; some detest them, so those with the Dao do not dwell with them. The noble person values the left in residence but the right in warfare. Those who delight in killing cannot achieve their aims in the world. Auspicious affairs value the left; inauspicious affairs value the right. When many enemies are killed, one weeps with sorrow; when victorious, one treats it with funeral rites. How grave is the lack of glory in victory and the lack of joy in killing! Tranquility means calm and quiet.

chunks.original_text: 道以无名为常但可谓之朴而已是朴也 夷也 希也 微也 可谓小矣 朴虽小万物皆自此生万物皆自此处出何所不统天下岂有敢臣之者乎 侯王若能守之则万物将自宾其和气所致天地相合以降甘露其盛德所孚人不待令而自均一守朴之效如此夫侯王之守朴也 守其常无名者而已守其无名始可以制有名礼乐政刑之属皆自此起然不可逐末而忘本也 名亦既有夫亦将知止而不过无求多焉 仍镇以无名之朴而已知止如此所以无危殆之患也 所以然者何也 譬道之在天下犹川谷之于江海川谷以江海为归天下以道为归但恐人君不知守此朴耳 知人者智自知者明胜人者有力自胜者强知足者富强行者有志不失其所者久死而不亡者寿 知人之是非者谓之智自知其得失者谓之明能胜人者谓之有力自胜其私欲者谓之强知足而无求者谓之富强行道而不息者谓之有志物变无穷知其所而不为所变者谓之久死生之变甚大虽死而未尝亡者谓之寿 智明力强以内外对言富而有志以能行知止对言久寿以不变于生不亡于死对言不失其所死而不亡皆守常道之效也 大道泛兮其可左右万物恃之以生而不辞功成不名有爱养万物而不为主常无欲可名于小万物归焉而不知主可名于大是以圣人终不为大故能成其大 大道之为体泛兮其可以左可以右执一求之而不得也万物恃之以生未尝辞也生物之功既成又不自名以为有爱养万物矣而又不为主自其常无欲言之希夷无形可名于小自其万物归焉而不知主言之容受无外可名于大道体之妙如此是以体道之圣人终不自以为大也故能成其大 执大象天下往往而不害安平泰乐与饵过客止道之出口淡乎其无味视之不足见听之不足闻用之不可既 能执大象以御天下则天下皆归往之矣天下皆往而我未尝有所作为而害之则往者无不安安而且平平而且泰矣此大道之为用也若夫作乐设饵以待来者过客非不止也乐阕饵尽将舍之而去矣道之出口淡乎其无味也视之不足见听之不足闻也及其用之则不可既岂乐与饵之比乎 陆希声云大象者道也苏子由云道非有无故谓之大象　乐饵盖喻小惠悦物者 将欲歙之必固张之将欲弱之必固强之将欲废之必固兴之将欲夺之必固与之是谓微明柔胜刚弱胜强鱼不可脱于渊国之利器不可以示人 天道之盈虚人事之倚伏皆有自然必至之势如将欲歙之也必已张之矣将欲弱之也必已强之矣将欲废之也必已兴之矣将欲夺之也必已与之矣此其理至微也而实至明是谓微明大要柔者可以胜刚弱者可以胜强而已此理可以自养亦可以自藏是鱼之深渊也此理可以御患亦可以为患是国之利器也鱼不可脱于渊脱于渊则死之徒矣国之利器不可以示人示人则或窃之而为害不胜言矣 道常无为而无不为侯王若能守万物将自化化而欲作吾将镇之以无名之朴无名之朴亦将不欲不欲以静天下将自正 道体本无而应用则有故常无为而无不为侯王若能守此道其于天下亦以无为此为之万物将自化而顺此无为之治矣万物既化苟有欲起而生其智巧者吾亦将以无名之朴镇定之且并此无名之朴亦将不欲守道至此可谓一无所欲而真能静矣天下有不各返于不欲而自正者乎 老子说略卷上 ●钦定四库全书

The Dao takes namelessness as its constant, and can only be called "uncut wood" (朴). This uncut wood is level, rare, subtle, and minute—one might call it small. Yet though small, the myriad things all arise from it, all emerge from it. What does it not govern? How could the world dare to treat it as a subject? If lords and kings can guard it, the myriad things will naturally submit. The harmony of qi brings it about that heaven and earth unite to send down sweet dew; the abundance of their virtue ensures that people do not wait for commands but distribute evenly. Such is the effect of guarding the uncut wood.

For lords and kings to guard the uncut wood is simply to guard that which is eternally nameless. Only then can one establish names. Ritual, music, governance, and punishment all arise from this. Yet one must not pursue the branches and forget the root. Once names exist, one must also know when to stop and not exceed. Seek no excess. Simply return to the nameless uncut wood to stabilize it. Knowing when to stop in this way is how one avoids peril and danger.

Why is this so? The Dao’s presence in the world is like rivers and valleys flowing into the Yangtze and sea. Rivers and valleys take the Yangtze and sea as their destination; the world takes the Dao as its destination. The only fear is that rulers may not know to guard this uncut wood.

He who knows others is wise; he who knows himself is enlightened.
He who conquers others has force; he who conquers himself is strong.
He who is content is rich; he who acts with vigor has will.
He who does not lose his place endures; he who dies yet does not perish lives long.

To know the right and wrong of others is called wisdom; to know one’s own gains and losses is called enlightenment.
To overcome others is called force; to overcome one’s private desires is called strength.
To be content and seek nothing is called wealth; to practice the Dao without ceasing is called will.
Amid endless transformations, to know one’s place and not be changed by them is called endurance.
The change between life and death is vast, yet he who does not perish even in death is called long-lived.

Wisdom and enlightenment, force and strength, are spoken of in contrast between inner and outer.
Wealth and will are spoken of in contrast between action and knowing when to stop.
Endurance and long life are spoken of in contrast between not changing in life and not perishing in death.
Not losing one’s place, not perishing in death—all are effects of guarding the constant Dao.

The great Dao flows everywhere; it can be to the left or right.
The myriad things rely on it to live, yet it does not refuse. Its work is accomplished, yet it does not claim credit.
It nurtures the myriad things yet does not act as their master. Always desireless, it may be called small.
The myriad things return to it yet do not know their master; it may be called great.
Thus the sage never acts as great, and so accomplishes greatness.

The essence of the great Dao is that it flows everywhere, able to be to the left or right. If one grasps for it as one, it cannot be obtained. The myriad things rely on it to live, yet it never refuses. Once the work of giving life is done, it does not name itself as having done so. It nurtures the myriad things yet does not act as their master. In its constant desirelessness, its rarity and formlessness, it may be called small. Yet the myriad things return to it without knowing their master; in its capacity to contain all without limit, it may be called great. The wonder of the Dao’s essence is like this. Thus the sage who embodies the Dao never considers himself great, and so accomplishes greatness.

The great image draws the world to it; they come without harm, at peace and secure.
Music and bait may make travelers stop, but when the music ends and the bait is gone, they depart.
The Dao’s utterance is bland, seemingly without flavor. Looking, one finds it insufficient to see; listening, one finds it insufficient to hear. Yet in use, it cannot be exhausted.

To hold the great image and govern the world is to have the world all come to you. The world comes, yet you have done nothing to harm them, so all who come are at peace, secure, and content. Such is the function of the great Dao. As for making music and setting out bait to await visitors, travelers may stop, but when the music ends and the bait is gone, they will leave. The Dao’s utterance is bland, seemingly without flavor. Looking, one finds it insufficient to see; listening, one finds it insufficient to hear. Yet when used, it cannot be exhausted. How can it compare to music and bait?

Lu Xisheng said: "The great image is the Dao." Su Ziyou said: "The Dao is neither being nor non-being, hence it is called the great image." Music and bait are metaphors for petty favors that please things.

If you wish to contract it, you must first expand it.
If you wish to weaken it, you must first strengthen it.
If you wish to abolish it, you must first raise it.
If you wish to take it, you must first give it.
This is called subtle clarity.
The soft overcomes the hard; the weak overcomes the strong.
Fish cannot leave the depths; the state’s sharp instruments cannot be shown to others.

The waxing and waning of heaven’s Dao, the rise and fall of human affairs—all have their inevitable tendencies. If you wish to contract it, it must first have been expanded. If you wish to weaken it, it must first have been strengthened. If you wish to abolish it, it must first have been raised. If you wish to take it, it must first have been given. This principle is extremely subtle, yet truly clear—hence it is called subtle clarity. In general, the soft can overcome the hard, and the weak can overcome the strong. This principle can be used for self-cultivation or self-preservation—it is like a fish’s deep abyss. This principle can also be used to manage calamities or become a calamity—it is like the state’s sharp instruments. Fish cannot leave the depths; if they leave, they become prey. The state’s sharp instruments cannot be shown to others; if shown, they may be stolen and cause immeasurable harm.

The Dao is eternally non-action, yet there is nothing it does not do.
If lords and kings can guard it, the myriad things will transform themselves.
If, in their transformation, desires arise, I will stabilize them with nameless uncut wood.
The nameless uncut wood will also have no desires. Without desires, through tranquility, the world will right itself.

The essence of the Dao is fundamentally non-being, yet in application, it is being. Thus it is eternally non-action, yet there is nothing it does not do. If lords and kings can guard this Dao, in governing the world they too will act through non-action. The myriad things will transform and submit to this governance of non-action. Once transformed, if desires arise to generate cleverness, I will stabilize them with nameless uncut wood. Moreover, this nameless uncut wood will also have no desires. Reaching this point in guarding the Dao, one can be said to have no desires at all and truly be tranquil. How could the world not return to desirelessness and right itself?

The highest virtue does not act as virtue—thus it possesses virtue.
The lesser virtue does not lose virtue—thus it lacks virtue.
The highest virtue practices non-action and does not act for any purpose.
The lesser virtue acts and acts for a purpose.
The highest benevolence acts yet does not act for any purpose.
The highest righteousness acts and acts for a purpose.
The highest propriety acts, yet when none respond, it rolls up its sleeves and forces compliance.

Thus, when the Dao is lost, virtue arises.
When virtue is lost, benevolence arises.
When benevolence is lost, righteousness arises.
When righteousness is lost, propriety arises.
Propriety is the thinning of loyalty and trust, the beginning of chaos.
Foreknowledge is the flower of the Dao, the origin of folly.
Therefore, the great man abides in substance, not in superficiality;
in reality, not in ornament.
Thus, he discards the latter and embraces the former.

The highest virtue does not claim possession of virtue—thus it possesses virtue.
The lesser virtue strives to hold fast and not lose its virtue—thus its virtue is incomplete and lacks true virtue.
The difference in their inner essence is as follows:

The highest virtue does nothing, not because it deliberately refrains from action,
but because it follows the natural course of virtue, with nothing left undone and no need for action.
The lesser virtue, however, must act—
deliberating before achieving, striving before accomplishing.
It cannot but proceed through action.
Their manifestations differ in this way.

Virtue is the name for the Dao embodied in a person.
As for those whose virtue is partial and renowned, there is the highest benevolence,
the highest righteousness,
and the highest propriety.

chunks.original_text: 道生一一生二无名天地之始也二生三三生万物有名万物之母也万物皆负阴而抱阳冲气以为和孰非道之生之成之者乎人之所恶惟孤寡不谷而制名者使王公自以为称欲其贵而不忘贱高而不忘下也故物或损之而适以益或益之而反以损谦与满之所自招也古人之所以教人者我亦取其言为教有曰强梁者不得其死岂非自益而反大损者乎是言也吾将以为教人之主 此章冲气为和以上似承善贷且成而言与下假文义不属或有脱误不可知解者皆牵合耳 道谓理一谓气二谓阴与阳三谓阴与阳与阴阳会合之气即下文所云冲气也万物负阴而抱阳冲气为和即申说三生万物也 此言生一生二与儒者不同此章惟李息斋注差明白可味 天下之至柔驰骋天下之至坚无有入于无间吾是以知无为之有益不言之教无为之益天下希及之 惟天下之至柔为能驰骋天下之至坚而役使之惟无有者为能入无间之内而无不达吾是以知无为之为有益也无为之为所谓至柔也无有也何所不驰何所不入乎然不言之教无为之益天下希及之矣盖叹其鲜能也 名与身孰亲身与货孰多得与亡孰病是故甚爱必大费多藏必厚亡知足不辱知止不殆可以长久 人之狥名者知有名而不知有身亦思名与身孰亲乎人之贪货者知有货而不知有身亦思身与货孰多乎狥名贪货者皆知好得而病亡亦思得与亡孰病乎是故有所甚爱则求之者必力而有大费所藏者厚则攻之者必众而至厚亡至此而始悟名之为身累也货之为身贼也得之为病甚于亡也若夫君子能知足则不辱能知止则不殆斯乃可以长久耳 大成若缺其用不敝大盈若冲其用不穷大直若屈大巧若拙大辩若讷躁胜寒静胜热清静为天下正 道德之大成者不自知其成也自视常若缺故其用不敝才能之大盈者不自以为盈也自视常若冲故其用不穷行之大直者循理而动不与物竞故若屈知之大巧者行所无事不为雕琢故若拙言之大辩者理有固然不以口争故若讷此清静之德也今夫寒热之气有形者之所不免而躁者可以胜寒静者可以胜热内之胜外如此岂有体清静之德而不为天下所取正者乎 天下有道却走马以粪天下无道戎马生于郊罪莫大于可欲祸莫大于不知足咎莫大于欲得故知足之足常足矣 天下有道无所事争却走马以粪田天下无道则日寻于争而戎马生于郊何以故罪莫大于可欲有可欲而以示人盗之招也祸莫大于不知足不知足而求益乱之所由生也咎莫大于欲得人之有欲得人之有大恶之所归也匹夫有此患必及之侯王而为此戎马所以生于郊乎故人能知其分之已足而自足焉则无不足矣无不足则不争矣 不出户知天下不窥牖见天道其出弥远其知弥少是以圣人不行而知不见而名不为而成 不出户可以知天下天下之为天下无待于出户而后知也不窥牖可以见天道天道之为天道固无待于窥牖而后见也若不知天下天道之所以然而求之于外出户而后知所知几何窥牖而后见所见几何即穷其所知所见以求之其出弥远其知弥少矣是以圣人之知天下不自天下索知也圣人之见天道不自天道起见也知不在外见不在外故不待行以求之而后知也不待目见而后名也不行而已知不见而已名且不必有所作为而已成矣圣人体道之功用如此其至也 为学日益为道日损损之又损以至于无为无为而无不为矣故取天下常以无事及其有事不足以取天下 为学者以求知故欲其日益为道者在返本故欲其日损损之者无欲不去亦无理不忘损之又损以至于一无所为而后与道合体焉为道而至于无为则可以物付物泛应无方而无不为矣故古之圣人取天下而化之正之者常以无事及其有事则为者将败之执者将失之何足以取天下乎

The Dao gives birth to the One;
The One gives birth to the Two—this is the nameless beginning of Heaven and Earth.
The Two give birth to the Three;
The Three give birth to the myriad things—this is the named mother of the myriad things.
The myriad things all bear yin and embrace yang;
The qi of the void harmonizes them.
Who is it, if not the Dao, that gives them birth and brings them to completion?

What people dislike are "the orphaned," "the widowed," and "the unworthy," yet those who devise names make kings and lords use these as their titles, wishing them to remain noble without forgetting their lowliness, exalted without forgetting their humility. Thus, things may be diminished yet benefit, or benefited yet diminish—this is what humility and fullness bring upon themselves. What the ancients taught, I also take as my teaching: "The strong and overbearing do not meet their natural end." Are these not those who, seeking to benefit themselves, instead bring great harm? I will take this saying as the foundation of my teaching.

In this chapter, the phrase "the qi of the void harmonizes them" seems to follow the idea of "bestowing and completing," yet the meaning below does not connect—perhaps there is a textual error, but it is impossible to know. Commentators all force interpretations.

The Dao refers to the Principle; the One refers to qi; the Two refers to yin and yang; the Three refers to yin, yang, and the qi where they converge—this is the "qi of the void" mentioned below. "The myriad things bear yin and embrace yang; the qi of the void harmonizes them" further explains how the Three give birth to the myriad things. This discussion of "giving birth to the One" and "giving birth to the Two" differs from that of the Confucians. Only Li Xizhai’s commentary on this chapter is somewhat clear and worth savoring.

The softest in the world gallops through the hardest;
Nothing enters where there is no space.
I thereby know the benefit of non-action.
The teaching without words, the benefit of non-action—few in the world attain them.

Only the softest in the world can gallop through the hardest and command it. Only nothingness can enter where there is no space and reach everywhere. I thereby know the benefit of non-action. Non-action is what is called the softest, nothingness—what can it not gallop through? What can it not enter? Yet the teaching without words, the benefit of non-action—few in the world attain them. This is a lament for their rarity.

Which is dearer, fame or life?
Which is greater, life or wealth?
Which is more harmful, gain or loss?
Thus, excessive love incurs great cost;
Hoarding much invites heavy loss.
Know contentment and avoid disgrace;
Know restraint and avoid danger—
Thus can one endure long.

Those who pursue fame know fame but not life—do they consider which is dearer, fame or life? Those who covet wealth know wealth but not life—do they consider which is greater, life or wealth? Those who pursue fame and covet wealth know only gain and not loss—do they consider which is more harmful, gain or loss? Thus, those who love excessively will strive and incur great cost; those who hoard much will be plundered and suffer heavy loss. Only then do they realize that fame is a burden to life, and wealth is a thief to life—that gain is a greater harm than loss. As for the noble person, knowing contentment avoids disgrace; knowing restraint avoids danger—thus can one endure long.

The greatest perfection seems flawed, yet its use is inexhaustible;
The greatest fullness seems empty, yet its use is boundless.
The greatest straightness seems bent;
The greatest skill seems clumsy;
The greatest eloquence seems inarticulate.
Restlessness overcomes cold; stillness overcomes heat.
Purity and stillness set the world right.

Those who achieve great perfection in virtue do not perceive their own perfection and always see themselves as flawed—thus their use is inexhaustible. Those of great talent and full capacity do not consider themselves full and always see themselves as empty—thus their use is boundless. Those who act with great straightness follow principle and do not contend with things—thus they seem bent. Those of great skill act without contrivance and do not engage in carving or polishing—thus they seem clumsy. Those of great eloquence rely on inherent principle and do not argue with words—thus they seem inarticulate. This is the virtue of purity and stillness. Now, the qi of cold and heat are unavoidable for embodied beings, yet restlessness can overcome cold, and stillness can overcome heat—so internally overcoming the external, how could one who embodies purity and stillness not be taken as the world’s standard?

When the world follows the Dao, warhorses are retired to fertilize fields;
When the world loses the Dao, cavalry horses breed in the suburbs.
No crime is greater than indulging desires;
No disaster is greater than not knowing contentment;
No fault is greater than coveting gain.
Thus, the contentment of knowing contentment is always contentment.

When the world follows the Dao, there is nothing to contend over, and warhorses are retired to fertilize fields. When the world loses the Dao, strife arises daily, and cavalry horses breed in the suburbs. Why is this? No crime is greater than indulging desires—indulging desires and displaying them to others invites theft. No disaster is greater than not knowing contentment—not knowing contentment and seeking more is the root of chaos. No fault is greater than coveting gain—coveting others’ possessions is where great evil converges. Even a commoner who harbors these faults will suffer them; how much more so for lords and kings who do so—hence cavalry horses breed in the suburbs. Thus, if one knows the sufficiency of one’s portion and is content, there will be no lack. Without lack, there will be no contention.

Without stepping outside, one knows the world;
Without looking through the window, one sees the Way of Heaven.
The farther one goes, the less one knows.
Thus, the sage knows without traveling,
Names without seeing,
Achieves without acting.

Without stepping outside, one can know the world—the world as world does not require stepping outside to be known. Without looking through the window, one can see the Way of Heaven—the Way of Heaven as the Way of Heaven does not require looking through the window to be seen. If one does not understand the world and the Way of Heaven as they are and seeks them externally, stepping outside to know—how much can one know? Looking through the window to see—how much can one see? Even if one exhausts all one knows and sees in seeking them, the farther one goes, the less one knows. Thus, the sage’s knowledge of the world does not come from seeking in the world; the sage’s vision of the Way of Heaven does not arise from seeing the Way of Heaven. Knowledge does not lie outside; vision does not lie outside—thus one does not need to travel to know, does not need to see to name. Moreover, one need not act to achieve—such is the sage’s embodiment of the Dao’s function, its ultimate expression.

To learn is to increase daily;
To practice the Dao is to decrease daily.
Decrease and further decrease,
Until one reaches non-action.
Through non-action, nothing is left undone.
Thus, to govern the world, one always does so without interference;
When there is interference, it is insufficient to govern the world.

Those who learn seek knowledge and thus desire daily increase. Those who practice the Dao return to the root and thus desire daily decrease. To decrease is to eliminate desires and forget principles, decreasing further until one reaches a state of non-action. When practicing the Dao reaches non-action, one can entrust things to their own nature, respond without fixed direction, and leave nothing undone. Thus, the ancient sages who governed the world and transformed it set it right by always doing so without interference. When there is interference, the doer will fail, and the holder will lose—how can this suffice to govern the world?

Non-interference is non-action. As the *Kaiyuan Commentary* states, it is like embracing transformation. The sage has no constant mind but takes the minds of the people as his own. Those who are good, I treat with goodness; those who are not good, I also treat with goodness—thus virtue is perfected in goodness. Those who are trustworthy, I trust; those who are untrustworthy, I also trust—thus virtue is perfected in trust. The sage, dwelling in the world, is ever vigilant, blending his heart with the world. The people all fix their ears and eyes upon him, and the sage treats them all as children.

The sage has no constant mind but only takes the minds of the people as his own. The people all desire their ruler to approve of their goodness and trust their sincerity. The sage, toward those among the people who are good, treats them with goodness; even toward those who are not good, he also treats them with goodness—thus his virtue is complete in goodness. Toward those among the people who are trustworthy, he responds with trust; even toward those who are untrustworthy, he also responds with trust—thus his virtue is complete in trust. The sage, dwelling in the world, is ever vigilant, fearing that the world may forget goodness and abandon trust. Therefore, he blends his heart with the world, regarding all equally without distinction. The people, meanwhile, fix their ears and eyes upon one another, observing and judging, each with their own right and wrong. The sage treats them all as children—seeing their right, he does not rejoice; seeing their wrong, he does not anger. Such is the sage’s taking the minds of the people as his own.
