If life and death are but emergent phenomena—emerging into life, then entering death—then, by rough calculation, among the people of this world, those who should attain life and thus belong to the living are but three in ten; those who should meet death and thus belong to the dead are but three in ten; and those who, while believing themselves alive, in truth move ever toward the realm of death are also three in ten. Why, when they take life as their aim, do they instead hasten toward death? Because they overindulge in the pursuit of life. The more lavishly they cherish life, the more urgently they rush toward death. Thus it is said: they seek life yet arrive at death. In sum, none of these are those who skillfully nurture life. It is said that those who skillfully nurture life do not encounter rhinoceroses or tigers when traveling on land, nor do they avoid weapons when entering battle. The rhinoceros finds nowhere to thrust its horn; the tiger finds nowhere to place its claws; weapons find nowhere to lodge their blades. Why is this? Because they are without the realm of death. That which is called the realm of death is the body itself. Only when one does not cling to the body, regarding life as but a temporary lodging and not cherishing it, can one be said to be without love for life—who then could bring about one’s death? Such is the one who skillfully nurtures life.

Most commentaries interpret "emerging" as manifesting from non-being into being, and "entering" as returning from being to non-being. To be "without the realm of death" means that the original nature remains eternally present. The Dao gives them life, virtue nurtures them; things take form, and circumstances bring them to completion. Thus, the myriad things without exception revere the Dao and honor virtue. The Dao’s reverence and virtue’s honor are not conferred by any decree but are ever spontaneously so. Therefore, the Dao gives them life, nurtures them, rears them, fosters them, ripens them, nourishes them, and shelters them. It brings them to life yet does not claim possession; it acts yet does not rely on its acts; it leads yet does not dominate. This is called profound virtue.

That which stands before all things is the Dao. It is the origin of the myriad things. Thus, all things are born of the Dao. When the Dao operates, it becomes virtue—this is the qi of yin and yang. It is the source upon which all existence depends. Thus, all things are nurtured by virtue. When qi gathers, things come into being, and only then do forms become visible. Therefore, things give form to it. Once things take form, their forms interact with the forms of other things, engaging and contending to create circumstances, and only then are the substance and function of things complete. Thus, circumstances bring them to completion. The forms of things are but the manifestations of what the Dao has given life to and virtue has nurtured. The completion of circumstances is but the fulfillment of what the Dao has given life to and virtue has nurtured. Therefore, the myriad things without exception revere the Dao and honor virtue. The reverence for the Dao and the honor for virtue—how could these depend on anything external? They are inherently and eternally so of themselves. Thus, the Dao endlessly gives life to things and nurtures them, and further rears them, fosters them, ripens them, nourishes them, and shelters them. Its merit in relation to things is thus, yet all occurs spontaneously. It gives life yet does not claim possession; it acts yet does not rely on its acts; it leads yet does not dominate. How could this be named or fathomed?

The world has a beginning, which may be taken as the mother of the world. Once one has attained the mother, one may thereby know her children. Once one knows the children, one must return to abide by the mother. Thus, one may endure to the end without peril. Block its openings, shut its doors, and to the end of life one will not toil. Open its openings, meddle in its affairs, and to the end of life one will not be saved. To perceive the small is called clarity; to abide in softness is called strength. Use its light, return to its clarity, and leave no disaster for the self. This is called practicing the constant.

The world has a beginning, which may be taken as the mother of the world—this is what one must embody and attain. Once one has attained the mother, one may thereby know her children, and nothing will remain unexamined or unaccomplished. Yet one must not pursue the branches while forgetting the root. Once one knows the children, one must return to abide by the mother. Only then can one endure to the end without peril. How does one abide by the mother? By blocking its openings and shutting its doors, so that to the end of life one labors not, yet merit is spontaneously achieved. Otherwise, if one opens its openings to seek accomplishment in affairs, one will remain in peril to the end of life, with no salvation. Can one fail to return and abide by the mother?

That which is seen yet cannot be seen is called the small. To perceive this unseen is called clarity. That which is guarded yet has nothing to guard is called softness. To guard this unguardable is called strength. Use the light that is outwardly manifest, then withdraw it and return to the inherent clarity of the root. Do not let it stray outward without return, lest disaster befall the self. This is called practicing the constant Way and merging with it as one.

All this speaks of embodying the Dao. The terms "beginning" and "mother" both refer to the Dao; "children" refers to the myriad things. To know the small and guard the soft is to abide by the mother. "Small" and "soft" echo the earlier chapter’s words on the subtle and imperceptible, the language of the Dao’s mystery. "Practicing" (袭) is like the *Zhongyong*’s "inheriting the earth and water" (下袭水土).

Were I to possess even a little knowledge, in walking the great Way I would fear only deviation. The great Way is very level, yet the people prefer byways. The court is excessively adorned, the fields are excessively overgrown, the granaries are excessively empty. They wear embroidered robes, carry sharp swords, sate themselves with food and drink, and hoard surplus wealth. This is called the boastful thievery of the lead reed—how far is this from the Dao!

Were I to possess even a little knowledge, in walking the great Way there would be nothing unknowable or impassable. Yet I would fear only ostentation, for it inevitably leads to losing the Way. The great Way is very level, fundamentally easy to follow, yet the people always prefer byways. What does this preference entail? Observe their court—excessively adorned, their governance—burdensome. Observe their fields—excessively overgrown, their granaries—excessively empty. Their fundamental occupations are abandoned. Instead, they wear embroidered robes, carry sharp swords, sate themselves with food and drink, and hoard surplus wealth—corruption flourishes. Great villains arise, and petty thieves follow. This is called the lead reed’s boastful thievery, the prelude to a chorus of discord. Truly, how far is this from the Dao!

What is well established cannot be uprooted; what is firmly embraced cannot slip away. Thus, descendants will continue their ancestral sacrifices without cease. Cultivate it in the self, and one’s virtue becomes genuine. Cultivate it in the family, and one’s virtue becomes abundant. Cultivate it in the village, and one’s virtue becomes enduring. Cultivate it in the state, and one’s virtue becomes prosperous. Cultivate it in the world, and one’s virtue becomes universal. Therefore, observe the self through the self, observe the family through the family, observe the village through the village, observe the state through the state, observe the world through the world. How do I know the world is thus? By this.

What is well established cannot be uprooted; what is firmly embraced cannot slip away. Transmitted without end, even to descendants, ancestral sacrifices continue without cease. That which is called well established and firmly embraced is nothing other than skillfully cultivating virtue. To cultivate virtue: cultivate it in the self, and with the self rectified, one’s virtue becomes genuine; cultivate it in the family, and with the family ordered, one’s virtue becomes abundant; cultivate it in the village, and with the village transformed, one’s virtue becomes enduring; cultivate it in the state, and with the state governed, one’s virtue becomes prosperous; cultivate it in the world, and with the world at peace, one’s virtue becomes universal. This is why it cannot be uprooted or slip away. How does one know whether virtue has been cultivated or not? Observe the self through the self, the family through the family, the village through the village, the state through the state, the world through the world—nothing more. How do I know the world is thus? By this.

chunks.original_text: 含德之厚比于赤子毒虫不螫猛兽不据攫鸟不搏骨弱筋柔而握固未知牝牡之合而■〈峻，血代山〉作精之至也终日号而不嗄和之至也知和曰常知常曰明益生曰祥心使气曰强物壮则老是谓不道不道早已 含德之厚者至比于赤子为赤子者毒虫不螫猛兽不据攫鸟不搏皆厚德之应也骨弱筋柔而握固不知牝牡之合而■〈峻，血代山〉作其气精纯之至也终日号而不嗄心不动而气和之至也知此至和之理者是之谓知常道知此常道者是之谓至明知其和知其常而守之不失则含德之厚可比赤子矣不然不知生之不可益而欲益之是菑诊欲至之祥气好胜而心复使之是谓不能弱而失之强物至于壮则必老恃壮者是谓不道不道则早已与含德者不大殊哉 知者不言言者不知塞其兑闭其门挫其锐解其纷和其光同其尘是谓玄同不可得而亲不可得而疎不可得而利不可得而害不可得而贵不可得而贱故为天下贵 知者不言言者不知知道者塞内出之兑闭外入之门挫已之锐解物之纷和已之光同世之尘是之谓忘物我混内外玄同于道者也亦安所恃言哉未能玄同者同乎此则异乎彼同乎始未必不异乎卒当其同也则亲之利之贵之及其异也则疎之害之贱之玄同之人无所为同也安有所谓异故不可得而亲亦不可得而疎不可得而利亦不可得而害不可得而贵亦不可得而贱故为天下之至贵 以正治国以奇用兵以无事取天下吾何以知天下之然哉天下多忌讳而民弥贫民多利器国家滋昏人多技巧奇物滋起法令滋章盗贼多有故圣人云我无为而民自化我好静而民自正我无事而民自富我无欲而民自朴 为君者以正道治国以奇变用兵以无事取天下吾何以知天下之可以无事取哉尝观天下多忌讳则失业者众而民弥贫民多权谋则国家眩于是而滋昏人不务本业而多技巧则珍奇无益之物滋起多为法令以制人则盗贼因之而愈多有此皆为上者多事之所致也知多事之足以病天下则知无事之足以取天下矣故圣人云我无为而民自化我好静而民自正我无事而民自富我无欲而民自朴盖言无事之足以取天下也 为化并读如讹或化读如归苏子由云利器权谋也 其政闷闷其民醇醇其政察察其民缺缺祸兮福所倚福兮祸所伏孰知其极其无正邪正复为奇善复为妖人之迷也其日固久矣是以圣人方而不割廉而不刿直而不肆光而不耀 为君者其政闷闷而广大欤则其民醇醇而知厚矣其政察察而烦苛欤则民缺缺而疎薄矣闷闷者若无得于民也而醇醇者应之察察者若大得于民也而缺缺者应之人见为祸而已为福之所倚人见为福而已为祸之所伏孰有知其究竟者哉方人之为察察之政其独未尝以正耶久之而正者复为奇矣善者复为妖矣察察之害如此人之狃目前之小福而忽远祸者其日固已久矣是以圣人方而不割廉而不刿直而不肆光而不耀去察察而取闷闷也正而不至为邪善而不至为妖此道得也 奇邪也妖怪变也刿伤也割也 治人事天莫如啬夫惟啬是谓早服早服谓之重积德重积德则无不克无不克则莫知其极莫知其极可以有国有国之母可以长久是谓深根固柢长生久视之道【柢一作蒂】 治人者不欲烦事天者不欲费二者皆如啬啬者敛退虚静之意夫惟啬是不待祸患之形而早自服习于道也早自服习于道是重积德于已也重积德于已则于天下之事将无所不胜于事无所不胜则其德之量又莫知其所极德之量莫知其所极则可以有国矣其有国也乃有其抚育一国之本是有国之母也斯可以长久治安而无患矣是道也以之治生则深根固柢长生久视之道也故治人事天皆莫如啬

One whose power is profoundly embedded is like a newborn babe: no venomous creature stings it, no fierce beast seizes it, no grasping bird of prey snatches it. Though its bones are weak and its sinews soft, its grip is firm. It knows nothing of the union of male and female, yet its organ stirs—such is the perfection of its essence. It cries all day without growing hoarse—such is the perfection of its harmony. To know harmony is to know the constant; to know the constant is to be enlightened. To seek to augment life is to court calamity; to let the heart direct the qi is to invite violence. When things reach their prime, they age—this is called not following the Way. What does not follow the Way perishes early.

One whose power is profoundly embedded is like a newborn babe: no venomous creature stings it, no fierce beast seizes it, no grasping bird of prey snatches it—all these are responses to profound power. Though its bones are weak and its sinews soft, its grip is firm. It knows nothing of the union of male and female, yet its organ stirs—such is the perfection of its pure qi. It cries all day without growing hoarse—its mind unmoved, its qi perfectly harmonious. To know this principle of perfect harmony is to know the constant Way; to know the constant Way is to attain perfect enlightenment. Knowing harmony, knowing the constant, and holding fast to them without loss—this is how one whose power is profoundly embedded may be likened to a newborn babe. Otherwise, not knowing that life cannot be augmented, one seeks to augment it, thereby inviting misfortune and courting calamity. When the heart commands the qi with a will to dominate, this is called failing to remain weak and instead forcing strength. When things reach their prime, they must age. To rely on strength is called not following the Way; what does not follow the Way perishes early. How vastly different is this from one whose power is profoundly embedded!

The wise do not speak; those who speak are not wise. Block the openings, shut the doors, blunt the sharpness, untangle the knots, soften the glare, merge with the dust—this is called mysterious sameness. Thus, one cannot be drawn near, nor kept at a distance; cannot be benefited, nor harmed; cannot be honored, nor debased. Therefore, such a one is esteemed by all under heaven.

The wise do not speak; those who speak are not wise. Those who know the Way block the inner outlet and close the outer gate, blunting their own sharpness, resolving the entanglements of things, softening their own brilliance, and merging with the world’s dust—this is called forgetting self and other, blending inner and outer, and attaining mysterious sameness with the Way. How can one rely on words? Those who have not attained mysterious sameness may align with this but differ from that, or align with the beginning but not necessarily with the end. When they align, they draw near, benefit, and honor; when they differ, they distance, harm, and debase. The one who has attained mysterious sameness does not align with anything—how then could there be anything called difference? Thus, one cannot be drawn near, nor kept at a distance; cannot be benefited, nor harmed; cannot be honored, nor debased. Therefore, such a one is the most esteemed under heaven.

Govern the state with uprightness, deploy troops with craft, and win the world through non-action. How do I know this is so? The more taboos there are in the world, the poorer the people become; the more sharp tools the people possess, the more troubled the state grows; the more cunning the people, the more strange things arise; the more laws and decrees are promulgated, the more thieves and bandits appear. Therefore, the sage says: I practice non-action, and the people transform themselves; I cherish stillness, and the people rectify themselves; I engage in no affairs, and the people enrich themselves; I have no desires, and the people simplify themselves.

To govern as a ruler, govern the state with the upright Way, deploy troops with craft and change, and win the world through non-action. How do I know that the world can be won through non-action? I have observed: the more taboos there are in the world, the more people lose their livelihoods and the poorer they become; the more the people rely on sharp schemes, the more the state is dazzled and grows troubled; the more people abandon fundamental work for clever tricks, the more useless and strange things arise; the more laws and decrees are made to control people, the more thieves and bandits multiply. All these arise from the ruler’s excessive meddling. Knowing that excessive meddling harms the world, one knows that non-action is sufficient to win it. Therefore, the sage says: I practice non-action, and the people transform themselves; I cherish stillness, and the people rectify themselves; I engage in no affairs, and the people enrich themselves; I have no desires, and the people simplify themselves. This speaks to how non-action is sufficient to win the world.

*(Note: The character "■〈峻，血代山〉" is here rendered as "its organ stirs," following the context of "essence" and "qi.")*

When governance is broad and unconstrained, the people are simple and honest; when governance is exacting and meticulous, the people are lacking and deficient. Misfortune!—fortune leans upon it; fortune!—misfortune lurks within it. Who knows their ultimate outcome? Is there no standard? The standard reverts to the strange, goodness reverts to the ominous. The people’s confusion has lasted long indeed. Therefore, the sage is square but does not cut, sharp but does not pierce, straight but not unrestrained, bright but not dazzling.

When a ruler’s governance is broad and unconstrained, the people are simple and know kindness; when governance is exacting and meticulous, the people are lacking and grow estranged. Broad governance may seem to yield nothing from the people, yet the people respond with simplicity; exacting governance may seem to gain much from the people, yet they respond with deficiency. People see misfortune and think it fortune’s support; they see fortune and think it misfortune’s hiding place. Who truly knows their ultimate outcome? When those who implement exacting governance believe they act with uprightness, over time, uprightness reverts to the strange, and goodness reverts to the ominous. The harm of exacting governance is thus: people grow accustomed to immediate small fortunes and overlook distant misfortune—this has lasted long indeed. Therefore, the sage is square but does not cut, sharp but does not pierce, straight but not unrestrained, bright but not dazzling—abandoning exacting governance and embracing the broad. Uprightness that does not become strange, goodness that does not become ominous—this is the attainment of the Way.

*(Annotations: "奇" means strange; "妖" means ominous or monstrous; "刿" means to pierce; "割" means to cut.)*

In governing people and serving heaven, nothing surpasses frugality. Only through frugality can one be said to practice early compliance. Early compliance is called the repeated accumulation of power. With the repeated accumulation of power, there is nothing one cannot overcome; with nothing one cannot overcome, no one knows one’s limits; with no one knowing one’s limits, one can possess a state. Possessing the mother of the state, one can endure long. This is called having deep roots and a firm foundation—the Way of long life and enduring vision.

In governing people, one should not seek to complicate affairs; in serving heaven, one should not seek to expend resources—both should be like frugality. Frugality means restraint, emptiness, and stillness. Only through frugality can one not wait for the appearance of misfortune before early compliance with the Way. Early compliance with the Way is the repeated accumulation of power within oneself. With the repeated accumulation of power, one will be invincible in all affairs; being invincible in affairs, the measure of one’s power remains unknown. With the measure of one’s power unknown, one can possess a state. Possessing a state means possessing the root that nurtures it—this is the mother of the state. This allows for long-lasting governance and peace without calamity. This Way, applied to life, is the Way of deep roots, firm foundation, long life, and enduring vision. Therefore, in governing people and serving heaven, nothing surpasses frugality.

chunks.original_text: 韩非子曰众人之用神也躁躁则多费多费之谓侈圣人之用神也静静则少费少费之谓啬又曰知治人者其思虑静知事天者其孔窍虚思虑静故德不去孔窍虚则和气日入语皆可味 治大国若烹小鲜以道莅天下其鬼不神非其鬼不神其神不伤人非其神不伤人圣人亦不伤人夫两不相伤故德交归焉【焦氏云烹不当加火】 治大国者不可以烦若烹小鲜之不可以挠治之以道而已人主诚能以道莅天下则其鬼寂然安于冥漠而不神非其鬼不神也其鬼虽神而不为厉以伤人若不神耳又非其神之自不伤人也圣人之治亦不伤人以和召和故神不伤人耳圣人不伤人圣人之德为之也两不相伤而德交归于圣人焉 亦字当善读乃追原语两不相伤亦谓圣人与神俱不伤人非谓人神不相伤 大国者下流天下之交天下之牝牝常以静胜牡以静为下故大国以下小国则取小国小国而下大国则取大国故或下以取或下而取大国不过欲兼畜人小国不过欲入事人夫两者各得其所欲故大者宜为下 大国者小国之下流天下所交会之国即天下之牝也牝之为物常以静胜牡以静为下知牝之道则知大国之道矣故以大国而下小国则取小国之心而为其所归以小国而下大国则取大国之心而为其所畜或下以取人或下而取于人为牝之益大矣尝观大国之情不过欲兼畜人小国之情不过欲入事人今大国亦能下而取小国小国亦能下而取大国两者各得其所欲矣故大者不可恃其大而宜为下也大者宜下况小者乎 道者万物之奥善人之宝不善人之所保美言可以市尊行可以加人人之不善何弃之有故立天子置三公虽有拱璧以先驷马不如坐进此道古之所以贵此道者何不曰求以得有罪以免耶故为天下贵 道者万物所藏以为安之奥善人治身治世之宝而不善人之所倚以自保也何以见其为不善人之所保人即不善苟有一言之美亦可以市于人一行之尊亦可以加人之上人之不善知悔而求道何至遽为人弃之有道为不善人之所保如此故天子所由立三公所由置亦以道在而人归之耳虽有拱璧以先驷马诚不如坐进此道之可贵也古之所以贵此道者何也不曰求以得有罪以免耶求以得故为善人之宝有罪以免故为不善人之所保而为天下贵也 为无为事无事味无味大小多少报怨以德图难于其易为大于其细天下难事必作于易天下大事必作于细是以圣人终不为大故能成其大夫轻诺必寡信多易必多难是以圣人犹难之故终无难矣 圣人所为者无为所事者无事所味者无味大视其小多视其少报怨以德图难于其方易为大于其方细盖以天下难事必起于易天下大事必起于细也是以圣人于天下之事终不待其大而后为之故能成其大若夫众人之轻诺者后必难复而寡信于事多见为易者后必多至于难是以圣人之于事犹难之故终皆可成而无难矣【焦氏云为营为也】 王纯甫云事所为之条件也味所谓之理趣也作起也 其安易持其未兆易谋其脆易判其微易散为之于未有治之于未乱合抱之木生于毫末九层之台起于累土千里之行始于足下为者败之执者失之是以圣人无为故无败无执故无失民之从事常于几成而败之慎终如始则无败事是以圣人欲不欲不贵难得之货学不学复众人之所过以辅万物之自然而不敢为【焦氏从韩非本作恃今断从诸本】 天下之事方其安易持方其未兆易谋方其脆易破方其微易散故为之者亦于其未有而为之治之者亦于其未乱而治之乃为善于为善于治者耳
chunks.translated_text:
Han Feizi said: The common people employ their spirit with restlessness; restlessness leads to great expenditure—this is called extravagance. The sage employs their spirit with stillness; stillness leads to minimal expenditure—this is called frugality. He also said: One who knows how to govern people maintains a tranquil mind; one who knows how to serve heaven keeps their apertures empty. A tranquil mind ensures virtue does not depart; empty apertures allow harmonious qi to enter daily. Every word becomes savorable.

Governing a great state is like cooking a small fish—through the Dao one oversees the world, and its ghosts do not act as spirits. It is not that its ghosts lack spirit; their spirit does not harm people. Since their spirit does not harm people, the sage likewise does not harm people. As neither harms the other, virtue converges upon them. [Jiao Shi notes: "Cooking should not involve adding fire."]

Those who govern a great state must not be troubled, just as cooking a small fish must not be stirred. Governing through the Dao alone suffices. If the ruler truly oversees the world with the Dao, ghosts will remain silent, at peace in obscurity, and not act as spirits. It is not that the ghosts lack spirit; though they possess spirit, they do not become malevolent to harm people, appearing as if they lack spirit. Nor is it that their spirit inherently does not harm people; the sage’s governance also does not harm people. Harmony beckons harmony, so spirits do not harm people. The sage does not harm people—this is the work of the sage’s virtue. As neither harms the other, virtue converges upon the sage.

The word "亦" should be read carefully: it traces back to the original meaning of "neither harms the other," referring to both the sage and spirits not harming people, not to people and spirits not harming each other.

A great state is the lower reaches, the confluence of the world, the female of the world. The female constantly overcomes the male through stillness, and through stillness, it remains below. Thus, if a great state humbles itself before a small state, it wins the small state’s allegiance; if a small state humbles itself before a great state, it wins the great state’s patronage. Therefore, some humble themselves to gain, while others humble themselves to be gained. A great state desires nothing more than to nurture others; a small state desires nothing more than to serve others. When both attain what they desire, the greater should act with humility.

A great state is the lower reaches of small states, the meeting point of the world—this is the female of the world. The female, as a creature, constantly overcomes the male through stillness and remains below. Knowing the way of the female, one knows the way of the great state. Thus, if a great state humbles itself before a small state, it wins the small state’s heart and becomes its refuge. If a small state humbles itself before a great state, it wins the great state’s heart and becomes its charge. Some humble themselves to gain others; some humble themselves to be gained by others—such are the benefits of being the female. Observing the nature of great states, they desire nothing more than to nurture others; small states desire nothing more than to serve others. If a great state can humble itself to win a small state, and a small state can humble itself to win a great state, both attain what they desire. Thus, the greater must not rely on its size but should act with humility—how much more so the smaller?

The Dao is the hidden essence of the myriad things, the treasure of the good, and the refuge of the unvirtuous. Fine words can earn respect; noble conduct can elevate one above others. Why abandon those who are not good? Thus, in establishing the Son of Heaven and appointing the Three Dukes, even if one presents a large jade disk followed by a team of four horses, it is not as good as sitting and advancing this Dao. Why was this Dao valued in antiquity? Was it not said: "Seek to obtain, and those with faults can be spared"? Thus, it is esteemed under heaven.

The Dao is the hidden essence in which the myriad things find peace, the treasure by which the good govern body and world, and the refuge on which the unvirtuous rely for self-preservation. How do we know it is the refuge of the unvirtuous? Even if a person is not good, should they possess a fine word, it can earn them respect; should they have a noble deed, it can elevate them above others. If those who are not good repent and seek the Dao, why would they be cast aside? The Dao is the refuge of the unvirtuous to this extent. Thus, the Son of Heaven is established, and the Three Dukes are appointed because the Dao exists, and people are drawn to it. Even if one presents a large jade disk followed by a team of four horses, it is truly not as valuable as sitting and advancing this Dao. Why was this Dao valued in antiquity? Was it not said: "Seek to obtain, for it is the treasure of the good; spare those with faults, for it is the refuge of the unvirtuous"? Thus, it is esteemed under heaven.

Act without acting, undertake without undertaking, savor without savoring. In great and small, much and little, repay resentment with virtue. Resolve difficulties when they are easy; achieve greatness when it is small. The difficult affairs of the world must arise from the easy; the great affairs of the world must arise from the small. Therefore, the sage never acts as if something is great and thus can accomplish greatness. One who makes promises lightly will lack trust; one who treats things as easy will encounter many difficulties. Therefore, the sage treats things as difficult and thus ultimately encounters no difficulty.

What the sage does is non-action; what they undertake is non-undertaking; what they savor is non-savoring. They regard the great as small and the much as little. They repay resentment with virtue, resolve difficulties when they are easy, and achieve greatness when it is small. For the difficult affairs of the world must arise from the easy, and the great affairs of the world must arise from the small. Therefore, the sage never waits for something to become great before acting and thus can accomplish greatness. As for the common people, those who make promises lightly will later find it difficult to fulfill them and lack trust in their affairs; those who treat things as easy will later encounter many difficulties. Therefore, the sage treats affairs as difficult and thus ultimately accomplishes them without difficulty. [Jiao Shi notes: "为 means 'to act'."]

Wang Chunfu said: "事 refers to the conditions of action; 味 refers to the principles and subtleties of things; 作 means 'to arise'."

When it is peaceful, it is easy to maintain; when it has not yet shown signs, it is easy to plan; when it is fragile, it is easy to break; when it is subtle, it is easy to disperse. Act before it comes into being; govern before it becomes chaotic. A tree as wide as a person’s embrace grows from a tiny sprout; a nine-story terrace rises from a pile of earth; a journey of a thousand li begins with a single step. Those who act will fail; those who grasp will lose. Therefore, the sage does not act and thus does not fail; does not grasp and thus does not lose. The people’s undertakings often fail when nearly complete. Be as cautious at the end as at the beginning, and there will be no failure in affairs. Therefore, the sage desires what others do not desire and does not value rare goods; learns what others do not learn, and returns to what the common people have passed over. Thus, they assist the self-so of the myriad things and do not dare to act. [Jiao Shi follows the *Han Feizi* version, which reads 恃; here, we decisively follow the other editions.]
chunks.overlap_context: in all affairs; being invincible in affairs, the measure of one’s power remains unknown. With the measure of one’s power unknown, one can possess a state. Possessing a state means possessing the root that nurtures it—this is the mother of the state. This allows for long-lasting governance and peace without calamity. This Way, applied to life, is the Way of deep roots, firm foundation, long life, and enduring vision. Therefore, in governing people and serving heaven, nothing surpasses frugality.

chunks.original_text: 试观合抱之木生于毫末九层之台起于累土千里之行始于足下何者不始于小而终于大乎 可不为于未有治于未乱乎 为之治之将如何亦因物之自然而已天下事有所作为者常败之有所固执者常失之圣人无为故无败无执故无失所以能为于未有治于未乱也 凡事又不特始者宜慎也 民之从事常于几成而败若能慎终如始则无败事矣 是以圣人以不欲为欲故不贵难得之货以不学为学故复众人之所过凡以辅万物之自然而不敢为也 是以圣人以下数句与上文不相属岂错简欤 古之善为道者非以明民将以愚之民之难治以其智多故以智治国国之贼不以智治国国之福知此两者亦楷式能知楷式是谓玄德玄德深矣远矣与物反矣乃至于大顺 古之善治道术者非以明民而使之智将以愚之使之去巧诈返淳朴也民之难治以其智之多耳我若以智治国则民亦将以智应之机诈愈深大乱将作是国之贼也惟安于无为而不以智治之则民亦将不识不知以顺吾治乃国之福也知此之为福彼之为贼则得治国之楷式是谓玄德玄德之为德深矣远矣且物方竞智而已独贱之与物情反虽与物反必如此乃上下和平至于大顺 江海所以能为百谷王者以其善下之故能为百谷王是以圣人欲上人以其言下之欲先人以其身后之是以处上而人不重处前而人不害是以天下乐推而不厌以其不争故天下莫能与之争 江海所以能为百谷王者以其善下之故能为百谷王是以圣人欲上人必以言下之欲先人必以身后之是以圣人处上而民不苦其重处前而民不忮害之不惟不重不害天下且乐推而不厌以其善下而不争故天下莫能与之争也 老氏疵处在此子由云圣人欲上人非欲先人也盖人下之后之其道不得不上且先耳增饰之词非其本旨诸文士解老佛书多类此 天下皆谓我道大似不肖夫惟大故似不肖若肖久矣其细也夫我有三宝宝而持之一曰慈二曰俭三曰不敢为天下先夫慈故能勇俭故能广不敢为天下先故能成器长今舍其慈且勇舍其俭且广舍其后且先死矣夫慈以战则胜以守则固天将救之以慈卫之 天下皆谓我之道则大矣 其人则似一无所能而不肖者夫惟大故似不肖若有所能而肖久矣 其细也 夫我有三宝常宝而持之三宝者一曰慈二曰俭三曰不敢为天下先此天下所谓不肖者也 夫慈则为人致福除祸行之不疑故能勇俭则积贮有余致用必裕故能广不敢为天下先则与物无忮人所乐推故能为材用之长三宝之为益于天下者如此今使舍其慈而徒为勇舍其俭而好为广舍其后而乐居先是人之所恶也 有死道矣 较之知所宝者何如乎 试以慈之效言之夫为上者尽慈之道则百姓亲附各出死力以卫其上以战则胜以守则固是天之将救是人也 故开其心使之以慈得众而卫之也 人知是人之以慈卫人也 不知实天之欲救是人而以慈卫之也 则世之残民以逞者其天之所绝乎 善为士者不武善战者不怒善胜敌者不争善用人者为之下是谓不争之德是谓用人之力是谓配天古之极 善为士者不尚勇武善战者恬淡而不怒善胜敌者不与之争善用人者身为之下有此善者是谓不争之德是谓能用人之力是谓能配合乎天之道此自古之极则也 用兵有言吾不敢为主而为客不敢进寸而退尺是谓行无行攘无臂扔无敌执无兵祸莫大于轻敌轻敌几丧吾宝故抗兵相加哀者胜矣 用兵者有言吾不敢为造兵端之主但后起应敌而为客吾不敢进寸而争人之有宁退尺而守巳之分是用兵而存不用之心若无行陈之可行无臂之可攘无敌之可扔无兵之可执也存心如此安有用兵之咎乎夫国家之祸莫大于轻敌轻敌几于自丧其宝故两国抗兵相加惟哀人之死而不乐杀者斯胜矣

Observe how a tree of great girth grows from the tiniest shoot; a nine-story terrace rises from a mound of earth; a journey of a thousand li begins with a single step. Is there anything that does not begin small and end great? Should one not act when things have yet to arise and govern when disorder has yet to emerge? To act and to govern—how should one proceed if not by following the self-so of things?

Affairs of the world often fail when there is forced action, and loss follows when there is stubborn attachment. The sage does not act and thus does not fail; does not grasp and thus does not lose. This is how they are able to act before things arise and govern before disorder emerges.

Yet it is not only the beginning that demands caution. The people’s undertakings often fail when nearly complete. If one can be as cautious at the end as at the beginning, there will be no failure in affairs. Therefore, the sage desires what others do not desire and does not value rare goods; learns what others do not learn and returns to what the common people have passed over. All this is to assist the self-so of the myriad things and not dare to act.

[The following several sentences of the sage appear disconnected from the preceding text—could this be a misplaced slip?]

Those of old who were skilled in the Dao did not seek to enlighten the people but to make them simple. The people are difficult to govern because they possess too much knowledge. Thus, to govern the state with knowledge is the state’s bane; to govern the state without knowledge is the state’s blessing. Knowing these two paths is also a model. To know the model is called profound virtue. Profound virtue is deep and far-reaching; it moves contrary to things and thus attains great compliance.

Those of old who were skilled in the arts of the Dao did not seek to enlighten the people and make them clever but to make them simple, to rid them of cunning and return them to purity. The people are difficult to govern because they possess too much knowledge. If I govern the state with knowledge, the people will respond with knowledge, and deceit will deepen, leading to great disorder—this is the state’s bane. Only by resting in non-action and not governing with knowledge will the people, not knowing or recognizing, comply with my governance—this is the state’s blessing. Knowing this as blessing and that as bane, one attains the model for governing the state. This is called profound virtue. Profound virtue as virtue is deep and far-reaching; though it moves contrary to the tendencies of things, only thus can there be peace above and below, attaining great compliance.

The rivers and seas can be kings of the hundred valleys because they excel in humbling themselves. Thus, the sage, wishing to be above the people, speaks as if below them; wishing to lead the people, places himself behind them. Therefore, though he dwells above, the people do not find him burdensome; though he stands before them, they do not find him harmful. Thus, the world delights in pushing him forward and does not grow weary of him. Because he does not contend, none in the world can contend with him.

The rivers and seas can be kings of the hundred valleys because they excel in humbling themselves. Thus, the sage, wishing to be above the people, must speak as if below them; wishing to lead the people, must place himself behind them. Therefore, though the sage dwells above, the people do not suffer his weight; though he stands before them, they do not find him harmful. Not only do they not find him burdensome or harmful, but the world delights in pushing him forward and does not grow weary of him. Because he excels in humbling himself and does not contend, none in the world can contend with him.

Laozi’s flaw lies here. Su Ziyou said: “The sage does not wish to be above or lead the people; it is only after placing himself below and behind that his Dao inevitably leads and precedes.” Such embellishments are not his original intent. Many literati who explain Laozi and Buddhist texts are of this sort.

The world all says: “My Dao is great and seems unworthy.” Precisely because it is great, it seems unworthy. If it were worthy, it would long since have been small. I possess three treasures, which I treasure and hold fast: the first is compassion, the second is frugality, the third is not daring to be first in the world. With compassion, one can be brave; with frugality, one can be expansive; not daring to be first in the world, one can become the vessel of leadership. Now, if one abandons compassion and seeks only bravery, abandons frugality and seeks only expansion, abandons the last and seeks only the first, this is death. With compassion, one will triumph in battle and stand firm in defense. Heaven will save them and protect them with compassion.

The world all says: “My Dao is great.” Yet others see it as if it were nothing, unworthy. Precisely because it is great, it seems unworthy. If it had worth, it would long since have been small. I possess three treasures, which I constantly treasure and hold fast. The three treasures are: first, compassion; second, frugality; third, not daring to be first in the world—these are what the world calls unworthy. Yet with compassion, one brings fortune to others and removes calamity, acting without doubt, and thus can be brave. With frugality, one accumulates abundance and ensures ample use, and thus can be expansive. Not daring to be first in the world means harboring no harm toward things, and thus people delight in pushing one forward, enabling one to become the vessel of leadership. The benefits of these three treasures to the world are thus. Now, if one abandons compassion and acts only with bravery, abandons frugality and indulges in expansion, abandons the last and delights in being first, this is what people detest—it is the way of death. How does this compare to knowing what to treasure?

Let us speak of the effects of compassion. If those above fully practice the Dao of compassion, the people will draw near and devote their lives to protecting their superiors. In battle, they will triumph; in defense, they will stand firm. This is Heaven’s intent to save such a person. Thus, by opening their hearts with compassion, they gain the people’s protection. People know that such a person protects others with compassion, but they do not realize that it is truly Heaven’s intent to save them through compassion. Then are those who harm the people for their own gain not doomed by Heaven?

One skilled in being a knight does not rely on martial prowess; one skilled in battle is not roused to anger; one skilled in defeating enemies does not contend; one skilled in employing others places himself below them. This is called the virtue of non-contention; this is called employing the strength of others; this is called matching Heaven—an ancient ultimate.

One skilled in being a knight does not exalt martial valor; one skilled in battle is tranquil and not roused to anger; one skilled in defeating enemies does not engage in contention; one skilled in employing others places himself below them. Possessing these skills is called the virtue of non-contention; it is called being able to employ the strength of others; it is called being able to match the Dao of Heaven—this is the ultimate principle since ancient times.

There are words on the use of arms: “I dare not be the host but act as the guest; I dare not advance an inch but retreat a foot.” This is called marching without marching, raising arms without arms, wielding weapons without weapons. There is no greater disaster than underestimating the enemy. Underestimating the enemy nearly costs me my treasure. Thus, when opposing armies meet, the one that grieves will triumph.

Those who use arms say: “I dare not initiate conflict as the host but respond as the guest; I dare not advance an inch to seize what others have but would rather retreat a foot to preserve my own share.” This is using arms while maintaining the mindset of non-use—marching as if there were no ranks, raising arms as if there were no arms, wielding weapons as if there were no weapons. With such a mindset, how could there be fault in using arms? The greatest disaster for a state is underestimating the enemy. Underestimating the enemy nearly results in losing one’s treasure. Thus, when two armies oppose each other, the one that grieves for the dead and does not delight in killing will triumph.

My words are most easy to know and most easy to practice, yet none in the world can know them, none can practice them. Words have their origin, affairs have their master. It is only through ignorance that I am not known. Those who know me are rare—thus I am esteemed. Therefore the sage wears coarse cloth while holding jade within.

My words are most easy to know and most easy to practice, yet none in the world can know them, none can practice them. Why is this? Words have their origin, affairs have their master. Only when one knows their origin and master can this be called knowing, and only then can one see how to practice. It is precisely because they do not know the origin of words or the master of affairs that, though they hear my words, they ultimately do not know me. Those who know me are rare—this is why what lies within me is esteemed. Therefore the sage wears coarse cloth while holding jade. How could this be something others could know?

To know yet not presume to know is excellence; not to know yet presume to know is a flaw. Only by regarding this flaw as a flaw can one avoid falling into flaw. The sage is without flaw because he regards flaw as flaw—thus he is without flaw.

When the people do not fear authority, then great authority arrives. Do not constrict their dwelling, do not oppress their livelihood. It is only by not oppressing that one avoids oppression. Therefore the sage knows himself but does not display himself, cherishes himself but does not exalt himself—thus he discards that and embraces this.

When the people do not fear punishment and authority, they will inevitably violate the law, and great authority will arrive. The reason the people do not fear authority is that their dwelling is constricted and their ambitions grow vast, their livelihood is oppressed and their desires multiply—thus they fall into death without concern. Each person has their proper place: be careful not to constrict their position, be careful not to oppress their resources. The people’s hearts have no constant—they follow what those above guide. Only when those above do not first oppress their own livelihood will the people likewise not oppress theirs. If those above favor extravagance, delight in wealth and abundance, how can the people’s ambitions be settled? Therefore the sage knows himself but does not display himself to impress others, cherishes himself but does not exalt himself above others—thus he discards the habit of constant competition and novelty and embraces tranquility.

To be brave in daring leads to killing; to be brave in not daring leads to life. These two may bring benefit or harm. What Heaven detests—who knows the reason? Thus even the sage finds this difficult. The Way of Heaven does not contend yet excels at victory, does not speak yet excels at response, does not summon yet comes of itself, is unhurried yet excels at planning. Heaven’s net is vast and wide—though it seems loose, nothing escapes.

Some use rigidity and force, being brave in daring, and thus inevitably cause killing. Some use softness and retreat, being brave in not daring, and thus can preserve life. These two may bring benefit or harm—all know they are not the same. To be brave in daring is what Heaven detests. Who knows the reason it leads to killing lies here? Thus, though the matter of bravery and daring concerns even the sage, he still finds it difficult, for he truly knows it is what Heaven detests. The Way of Heaven never contends with people, yet in the end nothing is not overcome. It never speaks, yet excels at responding to human affairs. It does not wait to be summoned yet arrives of itself in daily use, unhurried and at ease, as if forgetting others, yet excels at planning the success or failure, fortune or misfortune of all things. Heaven’s law is vast like a net—though it seems loose and wide, nothing is ever lost. The awesomeness of the Way of Heaven is like this. Once one violates what it detests, how can one escape?

The people do not constantly fear death—why use death to frighten them? If one could make the people constantly fear death and execute those who act strangely, who would dare? There is always an executioner who kills. To kill in place of the executioner is like hewing in place of the master carpenter—those who hew in place of the master carpenter rarely avoid injuring their hands.

The people’s nature does not originally fear death. Why, then, do those above use death to frighten them? If one could make the people constantly fear death and execute those who act strangely, who would dare to act strangely again? Yet killing does not cease, for one knows the people do not truly fear death. Thus those who rely on punishment to govern can now turn back. Moreover, when the people have crimes, there is always an executioner who kills them. If one acts on personal likes and dislikes to kill, this is killing in place of the executioner—like hewing in place of the master carpenter. Those who hew in place of the master carpenter rarely avoid injuring their hands. The executioner is the law. The sage establishes laws based on Heaven’s judgment—one cannot lightly weigh them with private intent. Those who abolish the law and act on emotion are warned.

The people starve because those above consume too many taxes—thus they starve. The people are difficult to govern because those above act excessively—thus they are difficult to govern. The people disregard death because they pursue life too fervently—thus they disregard death. Only those who do not make life their pursuit are wiser than those who value life.

The people starve because those above consume too many taxes—consuming many taxes exhausts the people’s strength, thus they starve. The people are difficult to govern because those above act excessively—acting excessively multiplies the people’s cunning, thus they are difficult to govern. The people disregard death because they pursue life too fervently—pursuing life fervently leads to insatiable greed, thus they disregard death. Only those who do not make life their pursuit: if above, they do not take excessively or act excessively to burden those below; if below, they do not dare to resist the net or commit crimes to trouble those above—are wiser than those who value their own lives.

In life, people are supple and weak; in death, they are rigid and strong. In life, plants and trees are soft and fragile; in death, they are withered and dry. Thus the rigid and strong are companions of death; the supple and weak are companions of life. Therefore, when arms are strong, they are not victorious; when wood is strong, it is felled. The strong and great dwell below; the soft and weak dwell above. From this, one can know what to discard and what to adopt.

In life, people are supple and weak; in death, they become rigid and strong. In life, plants and trees are soft and fragile; in death, they become withered and dry. Thus the rigid and strong are companions of death; the supple and weak are companions of life. Therefore, when arms are strong, they are defeated; when wood is strong, people fell it. All things that are strong and great commonly dwell below; the soft and weak commonly dwell above. From this, one can know what to discard and what to adopt.

Is not the Way of Heaven like drawing a bow? The high is pressed down, the low is lifted; the excessive is reduced, the insufficient is supplemented. The Way of Heaven reduces the excessive to supplement the insufficient. The way of man is not so—it reduces the insufficient to offer to the excessive. Who can take from the excessive to offer to the world? Only one who has the Dao. Therefore the sage acts but does not rely on it, accomplishes but does not dwell on it. Does he not wish to display his worth?

Is not the Way of Heaven like drawing a bow? When one draws a bow, the high is pressed down to lower it, the low is lifted to raise it. The Way of Heaven reduces the excessive and supplements the insufficient—its governance is of the same kind. The Way of Heaven reduces the excessive to supplement the insufficient, but the way of man is not so—it reduces the insufficient to offer to the excessive. Who can take from the excessive to offer to the world’s insufficiency? Only one who has the Dao can do this. Therefore, the sage acts but does not rely on his actions, accomplishes but does not dwell on his achievements. Does he not wish to avoid displaying his worth? Perhaps this is how one can reduce the excessive and supplement the insufficient.

Master Jiao said: When a bow is relaxed and the archer lowers his body, the grip rises and the tips point downward; when the bow is drawn and the archer raises his body, the grip lowers and the tips rise. This is pressing down the high grip to make it descend and lifting the low tips to make them ascend. The Way of Heaven reduces the excessive as if pressing down the grip to make it descend, and supplements the insufficient as if lifting the tips to make them rise.

Nothing in the world is softer or weaker than water, yet nothing can surpass it in attacking the hard and strong, for there is nothing that can replace it. Thus, the soft overcomes the hard, and the weak overcomes the strong. Though none in the world do not know this, none can practice it. Therefore, the sage says: "One who bears the disgrace of the state is called the lord of the altars of soil and grain; one who bears the misfortune of the state is called the king of all under heaven." These words seem contrary, for the world regards disgrace as shame and misfortune as calamity. How could they know that the soft and weak overcome the hard and strong? These are the true words that accord with the Dao.

To reconcile great resentment, there must remain residual resentment—how can this be considered good? Therefore, the sage holds the left tally and does not demand from others. Thus, one with virtue governs by the tally, while one without virtue governs by the tax. The Way of Heaven shows no partiality; it constantly bestows on the good.

If a man harbors great resentment and I seek to reconcile it, there will inevitably remain resentment that cannot be overcome. If one acts with intention to do good, one’s reach is limited—how can this be considered good? Therefore, the sage has no fixed intent toward things, like holding the left tally and awaiting others to come. When their tally matches his own, he does not go forth to demand from them. Thus, one with virtue does not calculate or contend—this is called governing by the tally. One without virtue fears inequality and measures gains and losses—this is called governing by the tax. Reconciling great resentment is also governing by the tax, and thus cannot be considered good. The Way of Heaven is the same: it shows no partiality toward men, yet what it bestows is always with the good. This is the good man’s own attainment—how could it be that Heaven constantly seeks the good to bestow upon them?

The *Record of Rites* says: "One who offers grain holds the right tally." The commentary explains: "A tally is a single document written in duplicate and separated. The right half is written first as the honored copy." This means that when offering grain, one must first present the right tally to the recipient. From this, we know that the left tally is held by the one who controls the goods, while the right tally is held by the one who seeks them. Thus, holding the left tally means awaiting others to come and match it before giving, without going forth to demand from them. "Governing by the tax" refers to those who calculate and measure gains and losses.

Let there be small states with few people. Though they have tools and weapons, let them not be used. Let the people value their lives and not migrate far. Though there be boats and carriages, let there be no occasion to ride them; though there be armor and weapons, let there be no occasion to display them. Let the people return to knotting cords and using them. Let them find sweetness in their food, beauty in their clothing, peace in their dwellings, and joy in their customs. Neighboring states may be within sight of one another, and the sounds of their chickens and dogs may be heard, yet the people may grow old and die without ever visiting one another.

I wish that those who are now lords would each be content with their small states and few people, not seeking to increase them. Let those who are their people each be content with their lot. Though they may have the talents and tools of ten or a hundred men, let them not seek to employ them. Let the people value their lives and not migrate far in pursuit of profit. Though they have boats and carriages, let there be no occasion to ride them; though they have armor and weapons, let there be no occasion to display them. Let them forget their cunning and return to knotting cords. Let each find sweetness in their food, beauty in their clothing, peace in their dwellings, and joy in their customs. Let them be inwardly sufficient and outwardly without desire, so that even neighboring states may forget one another. Though the sounds of chickens and dogs may be heard, and the lands be very near, the people may grow old and die without ever visiting one another. If this is so among the near, how much more among the distant? If there is no visiting, how much less will there be contention? Such is the governance of non-action.

Truthful words are not beautiful; beautiful words are not truthful. Good words are not eloquent; eloquent words are not good. The wise are not broadly learned; the broadly learned are not wise. The sage does not accumulate. Having acted for others, he has more; having given to others, he has greater abundance. The Way of Heaven benefits and does not harm; the Way of the sage acts and does not contend.

Truthful words are not beautiful; beautiful words are not truthful. Good words are not eloquent; eloquent words are not good. One who knows the Dao is not broadly learned; one who strives for broad learning does not know. Let us briefly describe the Way of the sage: the sage’s sageliness lies in having no accumulation for selfish ends, thus he constantly acts for others. Having acted for others, he has more; having given to others, he has greater abundance. The Way of Heaven benefits and does not harm; the Way of the sage acts and does not contend. The Way of the sage is simply the Way of Heaven.
